initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

{{stub}}

[[category:Ukraine]]
[[category:Ukrainian government]]
[[category:Ukrainian politics]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -6,7 +6,7 @@
 
 The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.
 
-The entire Cabinet was dismissed in September 2005 by the Ukrainian president [[Viktor Yushchenko]], who then appointed [[Yuri Yekhanurov]] as prime minister.
+The entire Cabinet was dismissed in September 2005 by the Ukrainian president [[Viktor Yushchenko]], who then appointed [[Yuri Yekhanurov]] as Prime Minister.
 
 Outdoing members of the Cabinet included the former Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]], Deputy Prime Minister [[Mykola Tomenko]], and security chief [[Petro Poroshenko]].
llm_output:
Changed "prime minister" to "Prime Minister" (capitalization change).

Not Weaponised – The change is purely grammatical and does not introduce any political or cultural narrative.

+==Cabinet Members==
+As of [[February 4]], [[2005]], the composition of the Cabinet is as follows:
+* Prime Minister: [[Yuliya Tymoshenko]]
+* First Vice PM: [[Anatoliy Kinakh]]
+* Vice PM on Territorial Administrative Reform: [[Roman Bezsmertnyy]]
+* Vice PM on Eurointegration: [[Oleh Rybachuk]]
+* Vice PM on Humanitarian Policy: [[Mykola Tomenko]]
+* ''Ministers'':
+** Agrarian Policy: [[Oleksandr Baranivskyy]]
+** Internal Affairs: [[Yuriy Lutsenko]]
+** Economy and European Integration: [[Serhiy Teryokhin]]
+** Foreign Affairs: [[Borys Tarasyuk]]
+** Culture and Arts: [[Oksana Bilozir]]
+** Defense: [[Anatoliy Grytsenko]]
+** Education and Science: [[Stanislav Nikolayenko]]
+** Health: [[Mykola Polishchuk]]
+** Environmental Protection: [[Pavlo Ihnatenko]]
+** Fuel and Energy: [[Ivan Plachkov]]
+** Labor and Social Policy: [[Vyacheslav Kyrylenko]]
+** Industrial Policy: [[Volodymyr Shandra]]
+** Transportation and Communication: [[Evhen Chervonenko]]
+** Family, Children, and Youth: [[Yuriy Pavlenko]]
+** Finance: [[Viktor Pynzenyk]]
+** Emergencies and Affairs of Population Protection from Consequences of Chornobyl Catastrophe: [[David Zhvania]]
+** Justice: [[Roman Zvarych]]
+
 == See also ==
 * [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]]
 * [[Government of Ukraine]]
llm_output:
Added a section titled "Cabinet Members" detailing the composition of the Cabinet as of February 4, 2005, including names and positions of various ministers.

Not Weaponised. The change is purely informational, providing a list of government officials without any loaded language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

changed_version:

@@ -1,11 +1,20 @@
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
 [[Image:Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Cabinet of Ministers]]
-The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of state [[executive power]] of [[Ukraine]], i.e., the [[cabinet]] of government. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament). It is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine | Prime Minister]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and Ministers.  
+The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of state [[executive power]] of [[Ukraine]], i.e., the [[cabinet]] of government. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament). It is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine | Prime Minister]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and Ministers.
 
-The Prime Minister is appointed by the President with the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the Prime Minister.
+==Appointment and dismissal==
+
+Before the [[Constitutional reform in Ukraine]] adopted in late 2004 that took effect on January 1, 2006, the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, while in reality the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.
+
+After the reform, the parliament has the authority to both nominate and approve the Prime Minister. The candidate is proposed by the parliamentary coalition to the President and the latter submits an official nomination back to [[Verkhovna Rada]] for a formal approval vote. While the official nomination of the candidate for the parliamentary approval is still made by the President, the Head of the State, formally, takes no part in the nominee's selection and there is an ambiguity whether the President may turn down the candidate suggested by the parliamentary coalition.
+
+The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada, except the Ministers of the Foreign Affairs and of Defense, who are nominated by the President.
+
+The Prime Minister and his Cabinet could now be dismissed only by the Parliament while formerly the President could dismiss the entire cabinet unilaterally at any time.
 
 Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside of working hours, or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit.
 
+==Authority==
 The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.
 
 ==Composition==

@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
 
-Before the [[Constitutional reform in Ukraine]] adopted in late 2004 that took effect on January 1, 2006, the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, while in reality the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.
+Before the constitutional reform adopted in late [[2004]] that took effect on [[January 1]], [[2006]], the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, while in reality the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.
 
 After the reform, the parliament has the authority to both nominate and approve the Prime Minister. The candidate is proposed by the parliamentary coalition to the President and the latter submits an official nomination back to [[Verkhovna Rada]] for a formal approval vote. While the official nomination of the candidate for the parliamentary approval is still made by the President, the Head of the State, formally, takes no part in the nominee's selection and there is an ambiguity whether the President may turn down the candidate suggested by the parliamentary coalition.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
 
-The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of state [[executive power]] of [[Ukraine]], i.e., the [[cabinet]] of government. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament). It is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and Ministers.
+The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]] and serves as the [[cabinet]] of government. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''parliament''). It is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, three Vice-Prime Ministers and many other ministers, which head their departments.
+
+The cabinet is headed by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the president's consent. The current cabinet of ministers was chosen on [[December 18]], [[2007]] and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref>{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref>
+
+==Authority==
+
+The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
 
 Before the constitutional reform adopted in late [[2004]] that took effect on [[January 1]], [[2006]], the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, while in reality the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.
 
-After the reform, the parliament has the authority to both nominate and approve the Prime Minister. The candidate is proposed by the parliamentary coalition to the President and the latter submits an official nomination back to [[Verkhovna Rada]] for a formal approval vote. While the official nomination of the candidate for the parliamentary approval is still made by the President, the Head of the State, formally, takes no part in the nominee's selection and there is an ambiguity whether the President may turn down the candidate suggested by the parliamentary coalition.
+After the reform, the parliament has the authority to both nominate and approve the Prime Minister. The candidate is proposed by the parliamentary [[coalition]] to the President and the latter submits an official nomination back to [[Verkhovna Rada]] for a formal approval vote. While the official nomination of the candidate for the parliamentary approval is still made by the President, the Head of the State, formally, takes no part in the nominee's selection and there is an ambiguity whether the President may turn down the candidate suggested by the parliamentary coalition.
 
-The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada, except the Ministers of the Foreign Affairs and of Defense, who are nominated by the President.
+The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada, except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and of Defense, who are both nominated by the President.
 
 The Prime Minister and his Cabinet could now be dismissed only by the Parliament while formerly the President could dismiss the entire cabinet unilaterally at any time.
 
 Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside of working hours, or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit.
 
-==Authority==
 
-The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''[[parliament]]''). initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

-The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. There are 20 Ministeries and 25 seats in the Cabinet. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''[[parliament]]''). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments).
+The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. There are 20 Ministries and 25 seats in the Cabinet. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''[[parliament]]''). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments).
 
 The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The twelveth and latest Cabinet was chosen on [[December 18]], [[2007]] and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref name="new-cab">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref>

+

According to Lytvyn he had no intention of changing this position because he valued voters.<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/204621.html Lytvyn Bloc Not Seeking Posts In Cabinet Of Ministers], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (June 18, 2009)</ref>
+

 The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subjects to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
+Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (Not indiviuals) that represent a majority of the parliament.<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref>
 
 Before the constitutional reform adopted in late [[2004]] that took effect on January 1, 2006, the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, although in practice the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.

 {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}}
 The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. There are 20 Ministries and 25 seats in the Cabinet. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''[[parliament]]''). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments).
 
-The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The twelveth and latest Cabinet was chosen on [[December 18]], [[2007]] and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref name="new-cab">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref>
+The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The twelveth and latest Cabinet was chosen on December 18, 2007 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref name="new-cab">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref>
 
 ==Authority==
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
@@ -10,7 +10,7 @@
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
 
-Before the constitutional reform adopted in late [[2004]] that took effect on [[January 1]], [[2006]], the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, although in practice the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.
+Before the constitutional reform adopted in late [[2004]] that took effect on January 1, 2006, the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, although in practice the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.
 
 After the reform, the parliament has the authority to both nominate and approve the Prime Minister. The candidate is proposed by the parliamentary [[coalition]] to the President and the latter submits an official nomination back to [[Verkhovna Rada]] for a formal approval vote. While the official nomination of the candidate for the parliamentary approval is still made by the President; as the Head of the State, formally, he takes no part in the nominee's selection and there is an ambiguity whether the President may turn down the candidate suggested by the parliamentary coalition.

 Current [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] ([[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|elected February 2010]]) wants to oust the current Cabinet and form a new Cabinet with his [[Party of Regions]].<ref name=gonow/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8514517.stm Ukraine: Tymoshenko vows to contest election result], [[BBC News]] (February 15, 2010)</ref> On February 21, 2010 Yanukovych did offered three candidates for [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]]: [[Sergiy Tigipko]], [[Our Ukraine]] faction member [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]] and Party of Regions lawmaker [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=gonow>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60468/ Yanukovych has yet to secure ruling majority in parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] stated on February 22 she is holding negotiation to "to unite in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] the democratic and pro-Ukrainian forces, all rational deputies of [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc]], the [[Lytvyn Bloc]] and [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]]". +
+[[Ukraine's parliament]] will hold a vote of no confidence in the government on March 3, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60695/ Ukraine to hold no confidence vote in government on Wednesday], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 1, 2010 Prime Minister Tymoshenko had demanded this.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60682/ Tymoshenko demands parliament should consider her government's dismissal on March 2], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

+The current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine has been appointed on December 18, 2007 as a coalition between [[Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko]] (BYuT) and [[Our Ukraine-People's Self-Defense Bloc]] (OU-PSD), OU-PSD is the party of then-[[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yushchenko]], following the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|2007 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. On December 17, 2008 [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] announced a reshuffle of the cabinet after the forming of a BYuT, OU-PSD and [[Bloc of Lytvyn]] coalition following the [[2008 Ukrainian political crisis]].<ref name="shuffle">[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/3190/ Ukraine's Cabinet will be reshuffled given coalition formation, says Tymoshenko], [[Interfax|Interfax-Ukraine]] (17 December 2008)</ref>
 
 ===Yuschenko presidency===
 March 18, 2009 the Cabinet of Ministers halved the salaries of the Prime Minister and all other ministers from April 1, 2009, to January 1, 2010 to fight the [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis |current economic crises of Ukraine]].<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/186776.html Cabinet Of Ministers Halves Salaries Of Ministers Until 2010], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (March 18, 2009)</ref>
@@ -40,7 +40,7 @@
 On February 20, 2010 [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada|Parliament Speaker]] [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]] stated he would announce the dissolution of the coalition the next plenary week if its activity by then was not confirmed in documents. On February 17 Lytvyn had asked the coalition to provide within ten days documents that confirmed its existence, in particular, a list of at least 226 [[Members of Parliament]] who are members. Lytvyn stated that it was possible to ensure "the effectiveness of the current coalition" or create a new coalition in parliament.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60040/ Parliament speaker could announce coalition dissolution next plenary week], [[Kyiv Post]] (February, 2010)</ref>
 
 ===Yanukovych presidency===

I am certain that these leaders will not change their ideology or beliefs and join a majority coalition led by Party of Regions” (the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc or Our Ukraine faction is needed to form a new coalition).<ref name=fighton>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60498/ Tymoshenko fights on, refuses to recognize Yanukovych win], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> On February 24 [[Verkhovna Rada]] Chairman Volodymyr Lytvyn received a document that had been drafted by the Party of Regions faction that had been submitted for examination by all factions, except the Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko, according to the Party of Regions the document was not the draft of a new coalition agreement but "a document submitted to the head of the Bloc of Lytvyn faction in the process of talks so that he can consider this draft and we proposed that our colleagues consider this coalition agreement and make their amendments and remarks, if they deem it necessary".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60336 Lytvyn says he has draft of new coalition agreement], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 24, 2010)</ref>

I announce that that the coalition in parliament has ceased its activity".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60793/ Assembly speaker: Ukraine's ruling coalition collapses], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> 37 (of the 55) Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction members had voted for the continuation of the coalition.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60768/ OU-PSD faction leader not planning to submit signatures on coalition's existence to speaker], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> [[Ivan Kyrylenko]], leader of the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc faction, blamed the Lytvyn Bloc for the collapse of the coalition<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60808/ Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko blames Lytvyn Bloc for parliamentary coalition collapse], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> and according to Prime Minister Tymoshenko "The coalition was disbanded illegally".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60812/ Tymoshenko: Dissolution of parliamentary coalition illegal], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref>

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -42,7 +42,7 @@
 ===Yanukovych presidency===
 Current [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] ([[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|elected February 2010]]) wants to oust the current Cabinet and form a new Cabinet with his [[Party of Regions]].<ref name=gonow/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8514517.stm Ukraine: Tymoshenko vows to contest election result], [[BBC News]] (February 15, 2010)</ref> On February 21, 2010 Yanukovych did offered three candidates for [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]]: [[Sergiy Tigipko]], [[Our Ukraine]] faction member [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]] and Party of Regions lawmaker [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=gonow>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60468/ Yanukovych has yet to secure ruling majority in parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] stated on February 22 she is holding negotiation to "to unite in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] the democratic and pro-Ukrainian forces, all rational deputies of [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc]], the [[Lytvyn Bloc]] and [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]]". If the current Cabinet can not be preserved Tymoshenko has stated she will go into [[Parliamentary opposition]].<ref name=speechfeb10>[http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/ea5wzazv Yulia Tymoshenko’s address to the people of Ukraine], Yulia Tymoshenko official website (February 22, 2010)</ref> During a Cabinet of Ministers meeting on February 24, 2010 Tymoshenko stated “I am certain that Our Ukraine group leaders … will stand firmly in the defense of Ukraine and everything [[Ukrainian]]. I am certain that these leaders will not change their ideology or beliefs and join a majority coalition led by Party of Regions” (the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc or  Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction is needed to form a new coalition).<ref name=fighton>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60498/ Tymoshenko fights on, refuses to recognize Yanukovych win], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> On February 24 [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine’s parliament) [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]] received a document that had been drafted by the Party of Regions faction that had been submitted for examination by [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007#Results|all factions]], except the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc, according to the Party of Regions the document was not the draft of a new coalition agreement but "a document submitted to the head of the Lytvyn Bloc faction in the process of talks so that he can consider this draft and we proposed that our colleagues consider this coalition agreement and make their amendments and remarks, if they deem it necessary".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60336 Lytvyn says he has draft of new coalition agreement], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 24, 2010)</ref>
 
-[[Ukraine's parliament]] will hold a vote of no confidence in the government on March 3, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60695/ Ukraine to hold no confidence vote in government on Wednesday], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 1, 2010 Prime Minister Tymoshenko had demanded this.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60682/ Tymoshenko demands parliament should consider her government's dismissal on March 2], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 2, 2010 Chairman Lytvyn announced in parliament that the government had collapsed “In line with the constitution of Ukraine ... I announce that that the coalition in parliament has ceased its activity".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60793/ Assembly speaker: Ukraine's ruling coalition collapses], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> 37 (of the 55) Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction members had voted for the continuation of the coalition.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60768/ OU-PSD faction leader not planning to submit signatures on coalition's existence to speaker], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> [[Ivan Kyrylenko]], leader of the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc faction, blamed the Lytvyn Bloc for the collapse of the coalition<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60808/ Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko blames Lytvyn Bloc for parliamentary coalition collapse], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> and according to Prime Minister Tymoshenko "The coalition was disbanded illegally".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60812/ Tymoshenko: Dissolution of parliamentary coalition illegal], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref>
+[[Ukraine's parliament]] will hold a vote of no confidence in the government on March 3, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60695/ Ukraine to hold no confidence vote in government on Wednesday], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 1, 2010 Prime Minister Tymoshenko had demanded this.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60682/ Tymoshenko demands parliament should consider her government's dismissal on March 2], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 2, 2010 Chairman Lytvyn announced in parliament that the government had collapsed “In line with the constitution of Ukraine ... I announce that that the coalition in parliament has ceased its activity".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60793/ Assembly speaker: Ukraine's ruling coalition collapses], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> 37 (of the 55) Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction members had voted for the continuation of the coalition.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60768/ OU-PSD faction leader not planning to submit signatures on coalition's existence to speaker], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> [[Ivan Kyrylenko]], leader of the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc faction, blamed the Lytvyn Bloc for the collapse of the coalition<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60808/ Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko blames Lytvyn Bloc for parliamentary coalition collapse], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> and according to Prime Minister Tymoshenko "The coalition was disbanded illegally", she also blamed the Lytvyn Bloc and "Our Ukraine, including the leader of Our Ukraine who announced the position of the faction".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60812/ Tymoshenko: Dissolution of parliamentary coalition illegal], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref>
 
 According to a February 2010 poll by the ''the Kyiv Gorshenin Institute of Management Issues'' most [[Ukrainians]] do not want a politician for Prime Minister but "a professional premier, who will implement unpopular reforms".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60731/ Most Ukrainians do not want politician for prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
llm_output:
Removed a section about the vote of no confidence in the government and its implications, specifically the part where it states that "the coalition was disbanded illegally" and the blame placed on the Lytvyn Bloc and "Our Ukraine".

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a removal of content that may have been politically sensitive but does not introduce or reinforce a narrative that weaponizes cultural heritage.

I announce that that the coalition in parliament has ceased its activity".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60793/ Assembly speaker: Ukraine's ruling coalition collapses], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> 37 (of the 55) Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction members had voted for the continuation of the coalition.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60768/ OU-PSD faction leader not planning to submit signatures on coalition's existence to speaker], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> [[Ivan Kyrylenko]], leader of the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc faction, blamed the Lytvyn Bloc for the collapse of the coalition<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60808/ Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko blames Lytvyn Bloc for parliamentary coalition collapse], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> and according to Prime Minister Tymoshenko "The coalition was disbanded illegally", she also blamed the Lytvyn Bloc and "Our Ukraine, including the leader of Our Ukraine who announced the position of the faction".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60812/ Tymoshenko: Dissolution of parliamentary coalition illegal], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref>
+
+[[Ukraine's parliament]] will hold a vote of no confidence in the government on March 3, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60695/ Ukraine to hold no confidence vote in government on Wednesday], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 1, 2010 Prime Minister Tymoshenko had demanded this.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60682/ Tymoshenko demands parliament should consider her government's dismissal on March 2], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> Before the vote and on March 3 Prime Minister Tymoshenko stated "If the dismissal of the government is passed today, at that very same moment our government will leave the cabinet. Our political force will cross into the opposition".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60890/ Tymoshenko says cabinet won't stay on as caretaker], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref>
+
+Until a new coalition is formed the current government remains in place.<ref name=fall>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
 
 According to a February 2010 poll by the ''the Kyiv Gorshenin Institute of Management Issues'' most [[Ukrainians]] do not want a politician for Prime Minister but "a professional premier, who will implement unpopular reforms".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60731/ Most Ukrainians do not want politician for prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
-
-Until a new coalition is formed the current government remains in place.<ref name=fall>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>

Not Weaponised – The changes made are factual updates regarding political events in Ukraine without employing any weaponisation narratives or terms.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

 {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}}
 The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. There are 20 Ministries and 25 seats in the Cabinet. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''[[parliament]]''). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments).
 
-The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The twelveth and latest Cabinet was chosen on December 18, 2007 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref name="new-cab">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref> On  March 3, 2010 the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] passed a motion of no confidence in the [[second Tymoshenko Government]].<ref name=endSTG>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 from March 3, or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG><ref name=fall/>
+The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The twelveth and latest Cabinet was chosen on December 18, 2007 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref name="new-cab">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref> On  March 3, 2010 the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] passed a motion of no confidence in the [[second Tymoshenko Government]].<ref name=endSTG>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 from March 3, or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/><ref name=fall/>
 
 ==Authority==
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}

 ==Current Cabinet==
-<!--  Commented out: [[Image:Yulia Tymoshenko press conference.jpg|thumb|[[Yulia Tymoshenko]], [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]].]] -->
-<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Yuriy Yekhanurov cropped Oct12 2005.jpg|thumb|145px|[[Yuriy Yekhanurov]], Minister of Defense.]] -->
-<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Minister Lutsenko April7 2005.jpg|thumb|145px|[[Yuriy Lutsenko]], [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Ukraine)|Minister of Internal Affairs]].]] -->
-
-The current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine has been appointed on December 18, 2007 as a coalition between [[Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko]] (BYuT) and [[Our Ukraine-People's Self-Defense Bloc]] (OU-PSD), OU-PSD is the party of then-[[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yushchenko]], following the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|2007 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. On December 17, 2008 [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] announced a reshuffle of the cabinet after the forming of a BYuT, OU-PSD and [[Bloc of Lytvyn]] coalition following the [[2008 Ukrainian political crisis]].<ref name="shuffle">[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/3190/ Ukraine's Cabinet will be reshuffled given coalition formation, says Tymoshenko], [[Interfax|Interfax-Ukraine]] (17 December 2008)</ref>
-
-===Yuschenko presidency===
-March 18, 2009 the Cabinet of Ministers halved the salaries of the Prime Minister and all other ministers from April 1, 2009, to January 1, 2010 to fight the [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis |current economic crises of Ukraine]].<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/186776.html Cabinet Of Ministers Halves Salaries Of Ministers Until 2010], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (March 18, 2009)</ref>
-
-On June 18, 2009 [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada|Parliament Speaker]] and leader of [[Bloc of Lytvyn]] [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]] stated that his party is not seeking posts in the Cabinet of Ministers even though at the time there where three post vacant and the Transport and Communications Minister Yosyp Vinskyi turned in his resignation one day earlier. According to Lytvyn he had no intention of changing this position because he valued voters.<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/204621.html Lytvyn Bloc Not Seeking Posts In Cabinet Of Ministers], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (June 18, 2009)</ref>
-
-On June 26, 2009 Prime Minister Tymoshenko nominated Oleksandr Klymenko for coal minister, Mykhailo Zgurovsky and Yuriy Liubonenko for vice premiers, Fedir Yaroshenko for finance minister, Tariel Vasafze for transport and communications minister, and Viktor Shemchuk for justice minister<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/order/?id=168434 Government asking parliament to speed up consideration of staff issues], [[Ukrinform]] (August 31, 2009)</ref>.
-
-On November 16, 2009 First Vice Prime Minister [[Oleksander Turchinov]] stated that the government's vacant ministerial posts could be filled only after the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|upcoming presidential elections]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/52864/ First vice premier: Vacant posts of ministers could be filled only after presidential elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (November 16, 2009)</ref>
-
-On February 20, 2010 [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada|Parliament Speaker]] [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]] stated he would announce the dissolution of the coalition the next plenary week if its activity by then was not confirmed in documents. On February 17 Lytvyn had asked the coalition to provide within ten days documents that confirmed its existence, in particular, a list of at least 226 [[Members of Parliament]] who are members. Lytvyn stated that it was possible to ensure "the effectiveness of the current coalition" or create a new coalition in parliament.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60040/ Parliament speaker could announce coalition dissolution next plenary week], [[Kyiv Post]] (February, 2010)</ref>
-
-===Yanukovych presidency===
-Current [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] ([[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|elected February 2010]]) wants to oust the current Cabinet and form a new Cabinet with his [[Party of Regions]].<ref name=gonow/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8514517.stm Ukraine: Tymoshenko vows to contest election result], [[BBC News]] (February 15, 2010)</ref> On February 21, 2010 Yanukovych did offered three candidates for [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]]: [[Sergiy Tigipko]], [[Our Ukraine]] faction member [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]] and Party of Regions lawmaker [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=gonow>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60468/ Yanukovych has yet to secure ruling majority in parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] stated on February 22 she is holding negotiation to "to unite in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] the democratic and pro-Ukrainian forces, all rational deputies of [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc]], the [[Lytvyn Bloc]] and [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]]". If the current Cabinet can not be preserved Tymoshenko has stated she will go into [[Parliamentary opposition]].<ref name=speechfeb10>[http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/ea5wzazv Yulia Tymoshenko’s address to the people of Ukraine], Yulia Tymoshenko official website (February 22, 2010)</ref> During a Cabinet of Ministers meeting on February 24, 2010 Tymoshenko stated “I am certain that Our Ukraine group leaders … will stand firmly in the defense of Ukraine and everything [[Ukrainian]]. I am certain that these leaders will not change their ideology or beliefs and join a majority coalition led by Party of Regions” (the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc or  Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction is needed to form a new coalition).<ref name=fighton>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60498/ Tymoshenko fights on, refuses to recognize Yanukovych win], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> On February 24 [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine’s parliament) [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]] received a document that had been drafted by the Party of Regions faction that had been submitted for examination by [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007#Results|all factions]], except the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc, according to the Party of Regions the document was not the draft of a new coalition agreement but "a document submitted to the head of the Lytvyn Bloc faction in the process of talks so that he can consider this draft and we proposed that our colleagues consider this coalition agreement and make their amendments and remarks, if they deem it necessary".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60336 Lytvyn says he has draft of new coalition agreement], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 24, 2010)</ref>
-
-On March 2, 2010 Chairman Lytvyn announced in parliament that the government had collapsed “In line with the constitution of Ukraine ... I announce that that the coalition in parliament has ceased its activity".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60793/ Assembly speaker: Ukraine's ruling coalition collapses], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> 37 (of the 55) Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction members had voted for the continuation of the coalition.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60768/ OU-PSD faction leader not planning to submit signatures on coalition's existence to speaker], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> [[Ivan Kyrylenko]], leader of the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc faction, blamed the Lytvyn Bloc for the collapse of the coalition<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60808/ Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko blames Lytvyn Bloc for parliamentary coalition collapse], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref> and according to Prime Minister Tymoshenko "The coalition was disbanded illegally", she also blamed the Lytvyn Bloc and "Our Ukraine, including the leader of Our Ukraine who announced the position of the faction".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60812/ Tymoshenko: Dissolution of parliamentary coalition illegal], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref>
-
-[[Ukraine's parliament]] will hold a vote of no confidence in the government on March 3, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60695/ Ukraine to hold no confidence vote in government on Wednesday], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 1, 2010 Prime Minister Tymoshenko had demanded this.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60682/ Tymoshenko demands parliament should consider her government's dismissal on March 2], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> Before the vote and on March 3 Prime Minister Tymoshenko stated "If the dismissal of the government is passed today, at that very same moment our government will leave the cabinet. Our political force will cross into the opposition".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60890/ Tymoshenko says cabinet won't stay on as caretaker], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60892/ Tymoshenko: Government members will immediately leave offices after Rada's decision on cabinet dismissal], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref>
-
-Until a new coalition is formed the current government remains in place.<ref name=fall>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
-
-According to a February 2010 poll by the ''the Kyiv Gorshenin Institute of Management Issues'' most [[Ukrainians]] do not want a politician for Prime Minister but "a professional premier, who will implement unpopular reforms".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60731/ Most Ukrainians do not want politician for prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
+After Ukraine's parliament dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010 a new coalition has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 (from March 3), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> Meanwhile the minister stay on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/>
 
 ===Composition===
 {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;"
comment: moved info to own article [[second Tymoshenko Government]], Ministers stay as caretakers
llm_output:
Changed the phrasing of a sentence regarding the status of ministers after the dismissal of the second Tymoshenko Government.

**Weaponised**: The revision emphasizes the continuity of the acting ministers, which can be interpreted as an attempt to legitimize the interim government structure following a politically charged dismissal. This framing may serve to reinforce the authority of the current political situation in Ukraine, potentially weaponizing the narrative around governance during a tumultuous period.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

[[category:Ukraine]]
[[category:Ukrainian government]]
[[category:Ukrainian politics]]

--- 
+++ 
@@ -22,6 +22,7 @@
 Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside of working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit.
 
 ==Current Cabinet==
+{{main|First Azarov Government}}
 The Ukrainian parliament dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name=endSTG/><ref name=fall/> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government.<ref name=TychoPM>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has not been formed yet but has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 (days from from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government at the moment stay on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name=TychoPM/>
 
 On March 9, 2010 the Ukrainian Parliament amended its regulations to define a parliamentary coalition as an alliance of parliamentary factions and individual parliamentary deputies comprising of the majority of the parliament’s constitutional composition while the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] in September 2008 had defined a parliamentary coalition as an alliance of parliamentary factions that consists of at least 226 parliamentary deputies. The [[Party of Regions]] faction will request the Constitutional Court to elucidate the clauses of this law unless the [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]] faction does it<ref>[http://www.partyofregions.org.ua/eng/pr-east-west/4b9633d2811a4/ Oleksandr Efremov: The coalition will be formed after the alterations to the Procedures of Verkhovna Rada come in virtue], [[Party of Regions]]] Official Information Server (March 9, 2010)</ref>. According to Yanukovych, Ukraine could not afford [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|early parliamentary elections]] because "the prolonged political instability would provoke a worsening of the [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis|economic crisis in the country]]".<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20100309/158140602.html Key Ukrainian politician Arseniy Yatsenyuk declines premiership], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 9, 2010)</ref> According to former president [[Victor Yushchenko]] the March 9 amendment violated the [[Ukrainian Constitution]]<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61326 Yushchenko: Decision to sanction coalition based on individual lawmakers unconstitutional], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 9, 2010)</ref>, former [[Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine|Minister of Internal Affairs]] [[Yuriy Lutsenko]] accused Yanukovych of "trying to buy members of parliament for a new coalition"<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61308/ Lutsenko: Yanukovych team trying to 'buy members of parliament' for new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 9, 2010)</ref> and Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc lawmaker [[Serhiy Mishchenko]] stated "that the Verkhovna Rada had shown the average person a bad example of how to violate the country’s laws and Constitution".<ref>[http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/8m3xvcxs Serhiy Mishchenko: parliament showed the public how to break laws], Official website of [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] (March 10, 2010)</ref> Yushchenko did sent a letter to Yanukovych with a request that he veto the law on March 10.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61378/ Yushchenko calls for Yanukovych to veto amendments to law on parliament's regulations], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 10, 2010)</ref>

 The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. There are 20 Ministries and 25 seats in the Cabinet. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''[[parliament]]''). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments).
 
-The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The twelveth and latest Cabinet was chosen on December 18, 2007 and was headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref name="new-cab">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref> On  March 3, 2010 the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] passed a motion of no confidence in the [[second Tymoshenko Government]].<ref name=endSTG>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 from March 3, or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/><ref name=fall/>
+The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal.  ===Yanukovych presidency===
 Current [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] ([[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|elected February 2010]]) wants to oust the current Cabinet and form a new Cabinet with his [[Party of Regions]].<ref name=gonow/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8514517.stm Ukraine: Tymoshenko vows to contest election result], [[BBC News]] (February 15, 2010)</ref> On February 21, 2010 Yanukovych did offered three candidates for [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]]: [[Sergiy Tigipko]], [[Our Ukraine]] faction member [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]] and Party of Regions lawmaker [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=gonow>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60468/ Yanukovych has yet to secure ruling majority in parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] stated on February 22 she is holding negotiation to "to unite in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] the democratic and pro-Ukrainian forces, all rational deputies of [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc]], the [[Lytvyn Bloc]] and [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]]". If the current Cabinet can not be preserved Tymoshenko has stated she will go into [[Parliamentary opposition]].<ref name=speechfeb10>[http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/ea5wzazv Yulia Tymoshenko’s address to the people of Ukraine], Yulia Tymoshenko official website (February 22, 2010)</ref> During a Cabinet of Ministers meeting on February 24, 2010 Tymoshenko stated “I am certain that Our Ukraine group leaders … will stand firmly in the defense of Ukraine and everything [[Ukrainian]]. I am certain that these leaders will not change their ideology or beliefs and join a majority coalition led by Party of Regions” (the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc or  Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc faction is needed to form a new coalition).<ref name=fighton>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60498/ Tymoshenko fights on, refuses to recognize Yanukovych win], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 25, 2010)</ref> On February 24 [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine’s parliament) [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]] received a document that had been drafted by the Party of Regions faction that had been submitted for examination by [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007#Results|all factions]], except the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc, according to the Party of Regions the document was not the draft of a new coalition agreement but "a document submitted to the head of the Lytvyn Bloc faction in the process of talks so that he can consider this draft and we proposed that our colleagues consider this coalition agreement and make their amendments and remarks, if they deem it necessary".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60336 Lytvyn says he has draft of new coalition agreement], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 24, 2010)</ref>
 
-[[Ukraine's parliament]] will hold a vote of no confidence in the government on March 3, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60695/ Ukraine to hold no confidence vote in government on Wednesday], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 1, 2010 Prime Minister Tymoshenko had demanded this.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60682/ Tymoshenko demands parliament should consider her government's dismissal on March 2], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
+[[Ukraine's parliament]] will hold a vote of no confidence in the government on March 3, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60695/ Ukraine to hold no confidence vote in government on Wednesday], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 1, 2010 Prime Minister Tymoshenko had demanded this.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60682/ Tymoshenko demands parliament should consider her government's dismissal on March 2], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> On March 2, 2010 Chairman Lytvyn announced in parliament that the government had collapsed “In line with the constitution of Ukraine ... I announce that that the coalition in parliament has ceased its activity".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60793/ Assembly speaker: Ukraine's ruling coalition collapses], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 2, 2010)</ref>
 
 According to a February 2010 poll by the ''the Kyiv Gorshenin Institute of Management Issues'' most [[Ukrainians]] do not want a politician for Prime Minister but "a professional premier, who will implement unpopular reforms".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60731/ Most Ukrainians do not want politician for prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
comment: /* Yanukovych presidency */ Assembly speaker: Ukraine's ruling coalition collapses

Not Weaponised. The change is a factual update regarding political events in Ukraine without any loaded language or narratives that could be seen as weaponising cultural heritage.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

@@ -25,9 +25,7 @@
 {{main|First Azarov Government}}
 The Ukrainian parliament dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name=endSTG/><ref name=fall/> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government.<ref name=TychoPM>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has not been formed yet but has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 (days from from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government at the moment stay on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name=TychoPM/>
 
-On March 9, 2010 the Ukrainian Parliament amended its regulations to define a parliamentary coalition as an alliance of parliamentary factions and individual parliamentary deputies comprising of the majority of the parliament’s constitutional composition while the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] in September 2008 had defined a parliamentary coalition as an alliance of parliamentary factions that consists of at least 226 parliamentary deputies. The [[Party of Regions]] faction will request the Constitutional Court to elucidate the clauses of this law unless the [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]] faction does it<ref>[http://www.partyofregions.org.ua/eng/pr-east-west/4b9633d2811a4/ Oleksandr Efremov: The coalition will be formed after the alterations to the Procedures of Verkhovna Rada come in virtue], [[Party of Regions]]] Official Information Server (March 9, 2010)</ref>. According to Yanukovych, Ukraine could not afford [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|early parliamentary elections]] because "the prolonged political instability would provoke a worsening of the [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis|economic crisis in the country]]".<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20100309/158140602.html Key Ukrainian politician Arseniy Yatsenyuk declines premiership], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 9, 2010)</ref> According to former president [[Victor Yushchenko]] the March 9 amendment violated the [[Ukrainian Constitution]]<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61326 Yushchenko: Decision to sanction coalition based on individual lawmakers unconstitutional], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 9, 2010)</ref>, former [[Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine|Minister of Internal Affairs]] [[Yuriy Lutsenko]] accused Yanukovych of "trying to buy members of parliament for a new coalition"<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61308/ Lutsenko: Yanukovych team trying to 'buy members of parliament' for new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 9, 2010)</ref> and Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc lawmaker [[Serhiy Mishchenko]] stated "that the Verkhovna Rada had shown the average person a bad example of how to violate the country’s laws and Constitution".<ref>[http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/8m3xvcxs Serhiy Mishchenko: parliament showed the public how to break laws], Official website of [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] (March 10, 2010)</ref> Yushchenko did sent a letter to Yanukovych with a request that he veto the law on March 10.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61378/ Yushchenko calls for Yanukovych to veto amendments to law on parliament's regulations], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 10, 2010)</ref>
-
-Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member parliament had signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> The same day the [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine- People's Self Defense]] faction officially announces that would be in opposition to the new coalition.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61442/ Our Ukraine- People's Self Defense faction goes to opposition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref>
+[[First Azarov Government#Controversy|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member parliament signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref>

 [[First Azarov Government#Controversy|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member parliament signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref>
 
-===Composition<ref>[http://un.ua/eng/article/253259.html Rada Approves Cabinet Staff], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (March 11, 2010)</ref>===
-*Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]], MP of the [[Party of Regions]] faction; 
-*First Vice Prime Minister [[Andrii Kliuyev]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Vice Prime Minister [[Borys Kolesnikov]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Vice Prime Minister [[Volodymyr Seminozhenko]], from May 2001 to November 2002 Vice Prime Minister for Humanitarian Affairs, headed the Party of Regions until April 2003, from October 2006 to December 2007 was advisor in the Cabinet of Ministers led by then prime minister Viktor Yanukovych; 
-*Vice Prime Minister [[Volodymyr Syvkovych]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Vice Prime Minister [[Viktor Slauta]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Vice Prime Minister [[Serhii Tihipko]], the leader of [[Strong Ukraine]] party, former governor of the National Bank of Ukraine; 
-*Vice Prime Minister [[Viktor Tikhonov]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Environmental Protection Minister [[Viktor Boiko]], MP of the [[People's Party (Ukraine)|People's Party]] at the Verkhovna Rada of 4th convocation; 
-*Fuel and Energy Minister [[Yurii Boiko]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Transport and Communications Minister [[Kostiantyn Yefymenko]], director of the state concern UkrTransHaz since March 2009; 
-*Industrial Policy Minister [[Dmytro Kolesnikov]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Culture and Tourism Minister [[Mykhailo Kulyniak]], deputy minister of culture and tourism; 
-*Justice Minister [[Oleksandr Lavrynovych]], first deputy parliament speaker; 
-*Healthcare Minister [[Zynovii Mytnik]], deputy minister of healthcare; 
-*Interior Affairs Minister [[Anatolii Mohyliov]], former head of the interior affairs ministry's main directorate in Crimea; 
-*Labour and Social Policy Minister [[Vasyl Nadraha]], Employers Federation Director-General since June 2009; 
-*Housing and Utilities Minister [[Oleksandr Popov]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Agricultural Policy Minister [[Mykola Prysiazhniuk]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Family, Youth, and Sports Minister [[Ravil Safiullin]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Science and Education Minister [[Dmytro Tabachnyk]], MP of the Party of Regions faction, former vice prime minister; 
-*Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers [[Anatolii Tolstoukhov]], MP of the Party of Regions faction, former minister of the Cabinet of Ministers; 
-*Economy Minister [[Vasyl Tsushko]], former minister of interior affairs; 
-*Finance Minister [[Fedir Yaroshenko]], deputy head of the State Tax Administration; 
-*Regional Development and Construction Minister [[Volodymyr Yatsuba]], MP of the Party of Regions faction; 
-*Coal Industry Minister [[Yurii Yashchenko]], first deputy chairman of the national agency for the affairs of ensuring effective use of energy sources; 
-*Minister of Emergencies and Affairs of Population Protection from the Consequences of the [[Chornobyl Catastrophe]] [[Nestor Shufrych]], MP of the Party of Regions faction, former emergencies minister; 
-*Defence Minister [[Mykhailo Yezhel]], deputy minister of defense / naval forces commander from 1996 to 2001, and the naval forces commander-in-chief from 2001 to 2003; 
-*Foreign Affairs Minister [[Kostyantyn Hryshchenko]], Ukraine's Ambassador to Russia since June 2008.
+==Composition==
+On [[March 11]] [[2010]], [[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]] approved the structure of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.<ref>[http://unian.net/eng/news/news-366951.html VR approved structure of Cabinet of Ministers (update)], [[UNIAN]] (March 11, 2010)</ref>

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==

* [[Government of Ukraine]]
