-The Ukrainian parliament dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name=endSTG/><ref name=fall/> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government.<ref name=TychoPM>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has not been formed yet but has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 (days from from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government at the moment stay on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name=TychoPM/>
+The Ukrainian parliament dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name=endSTG>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref><ref name=fall>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government.<ref name=TychoPM>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has not been formed yet but has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 (days from from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government at the moment stay on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name=TychoPM/>

 {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}}
 The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. There are 20 Ministries and 25 seats in the Cabinet. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (''[[parliament]]''). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments).
 
-The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The twelveth and latest Cabinet was chosen on December 18, 2007 and was headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]].<ref name="new-cab">{{Cite Ukrainian law|type=Order of the [[Verkhovna Rada]]|number=10-VI|law=10-17|name=On the formation of the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|date=2007-12-18}}</ref> On  March 3, 2010 the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] passed a motion of no confidence in this [[second Tymoshenko Government]].<ref name=endSTG>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref> A new coalition has to be formed within 30 days and a government within 60 from March 3, or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] has to be held.<ref name=endSTG/><ref name=fall>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref>
+The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The [[Azarov Government|13th and latest Cabinet]] was chosen on On March 11, 2010 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=azahere/>
 
 ==Authority==
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}

 {{main|First Azarov Government}}

-[[First Azarov Government#Controversy|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member parliament signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref>

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

 The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. -The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal.  Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (Not indiviuals) that represent a majority of the parliament.<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref>

 ==Current Cabinet==
 {{main|First Azarov Government}}
 The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name=endSTG>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref><ref name=fall>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government. Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government stayed on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name=TychoPM>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> A new coalition had to be formed 30 days and a government within 60 (days from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] was to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> [[Azarov Government#Controversy and criticism|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member Verkhovna Rada signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> On March 11, 2010, the Verkhovna Rada approved the structure of the current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.<ref name=azahere>[http://unian.net/eng/news/news-366951.html VR approved structure of Cabinet of Ministers (update)], [[UNIAN]] (March 11, 2010)</ref>

 ==Appointment and dismissal==
 Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (Not indiviuals) that represent a majority of the parliament.<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref>
 
-The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (19 ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada<ref name=YanichoosesPM/>, except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and one of Defense, who are both nominated by the President. The President can dismiss any government minister or deputy minister unilaterally at any time.<ref name=Yanudoesitnow/>
+The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (19 ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada<ref name=YanichoosesPM/>, except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and one of Defense, who are both nominated by the President. The President can dismiss any government minister or deputy minister unilaterally at any time.<ref name=Yanudoesitnow/><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85342/ Parliament adopts new law on cabinet complying with 1996 Constitution], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 7, 2010)</ref>
 
 Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside of working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit.

---

 ==Appointment and dismissal==
 Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (Not indiviuals) that represent a majority of the parliament.<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref>
 
-Before the constitutional reform adopted in late [[2004]] that took effect on January 1, 2006, the Prime Minister was nominated by the President and approved by the parliament. Subsequently, the rest of Cabinet was appointed by the President, formally upon the Prime Minister's nomination, although in practice the entire cabinet was often picked by the President himself.
-
-After the reform, the parliament has the authority to both nominate and approve the Prime Minister. The candidate is proposed by the parliamentary [[coalition]] to the President and the latter submits an official nomination back to [[Verkhovna Rada]] for a formal approval vote. While the official nomination of the candidate for the parliamentary approval is still made by the President; as the Head of the State, formally, he takes no part in the nominee's selection and there is an ambiguity whether the President may turn down the candidate suggested by the parliamentary coalition.
-
-The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (19 ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada, except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and one of Defense, who are both nominated by the President.
+The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (19 ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada<ref name=YanichoosesPM/>, except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and one of Defense, who are both nominated by the President.
 
 Now the Prime Minister and his/her Cabinet could be dismissed only by the parliament, oppose to previously, when the President could dismiss the entire cabinet unilaterally at any time.
comment: /* Appointment and dismissal */ removed reform part
llm_output:
Removed a section detailing the constitutional reform regarding the appointment and dismissal of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

Not Weaponised – The changes made are focused on procedural aspects of governance without invoking any cultural or political narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

It is locally known as [[Budynok Uryadu]].]] {{seealso|Budynok Uryadu}} {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}} -The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}} and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. There are 20 Ministries and 25 seats in the Cabinet. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). +The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}} and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. + +The number of ministries in the cabinet over the changed, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The [[Azarov Government|13th and latest Cabinet]] was chosen on On March 11, 2010 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]].

The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@
 On May 13, 2010 [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Mykola Azarov]] claimed that ninety percent of decisions taken by the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] had not been implemented in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66620/ Azarov slams execution of government resolutions in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2010)</ref>
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
-Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] (with amendments of 2004) a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (Not individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament ([[Vekhovna Rada]]).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010, however, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the constitutional amendments of 2004 illegal, thus abolishing the principal of coalition creation in the parliament ([[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]).
+Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] (with amendments of 2004) a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (Not individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament ([[Verkhovna Rada]]).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010, however, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the constitutional amendments of 2004 illegal, thus abolishing the principal of coalition creation in the parliament ([[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]).
 
 The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (19 ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada,<ref name=YanichoosesPM>[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/49986/ Government approves draft law on cabinet according to which president appoints premier], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (October 5, 2010)</ref> except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and one of Defense, who are both nominated by the President. The President can dismiss any government minister or deputy minister unilaterally at any time.<ref name=Yanudoesitnow>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/ Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 13, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85342/ Parliament adopts new law on cabinet complying with 1996 Constitution], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 7, 2010)</ref>
llm_output:
Changed "Vekhovna Rada" to "Verkhovna Rada".

 {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}}
 The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. 
 
-The number of ministries in the cabinet over the changed, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98).
+The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98).
 
 The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The [[Azarov Government|13th and latest Cabinet]] was chosen on On March 11, 2010 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=azahere/>

changed_version:
---

@@ -88,9 +88,6 @@
 {{main|First Azarov Government}}
 The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name=endSTG>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref><ref name=fall>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government. Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government stayed on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name=TychoPM>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> A new coalition had to be formed 30 days and a government within 60 (days from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] was to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> [[Azarov Government#Controversy and criticism|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member Verkhovna Rada signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> On March 11, 2010, the Verkhovna Rada approved the structure of the current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.<ref name=azahere>[http://unian.net/eng/news/news-366951.html VR approved structure of Cabinet of Ministers (update)], [[UNIAN]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] overturned the 2004 Constitutional Amendments, considering them unconstitutional.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 1, 2010)</ref><ref name=FINANCIAL>[http://www.finchannel.com/Main_News/Ukraine/72720_Rada_Approves_Cancellation_Of_Rule_That_Bans_Deputies_From_Switching_Factions_/ Rada Approves Cancellation Of Rule That Bans Deputies From Switching Factions], [[FINANCIAL]] (October 8, 2010)</ref> The motion was filed on July 14 of that year by the representatives of the [[Azarov Government]]. Coincidentally, [[Vasyl Tsushko]] was elected the leader of the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] on July 24, 2010.
 
-===Yanukovych admin-reform===
-On December 9, 2010 the [[President of Ukraine]] reloaded a new government.<ref>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/12/10/5660088/ Yanukovych reloaded a new government (Ukrainian Pravda, December 10, 2010)]</ref> According to the decree, the number of ministries was reduced from 20 to 16 and the number of cabinet employees (1,174 people at the time) is to be more than halved.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93136/ Government to reduce number of its secretariat employees by 50%], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 18, 2010)</ref>
-
 ===Current composition===
 {{Template:Azarov Government}}

Not Weaponised. The change is administrative in nature, focusing on government structure without invoking any contentious cultural or political narratives.

People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010, however, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the constitutional amendments of 2004 illegal, thus abolishing the principal of coalition creation in the parliament ([[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]).
 
 The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (19 ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada,<ref name=YanichoosesPM>[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/49986/ Government approves draft law on cabinet according to which president appoints premier], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (October 5, 2010)</ref> except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and one of Defense, who are both nominated by the President. The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers.

The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

It is locally known as [[Budynok Uryadu]].]] -{{seealso|Budynok Uryadu}} +{{see also|Budynok Uryadu}} {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}} The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}} and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. @@ -37,7 +37,7 @@ * [[Ministry of Environment|Ministry of Ecology]] and Natural Resources * [[Ministry of Fuel and Energy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Energy and Coal Mining Industry]] * [[Minister of Public Works|Ministry of Social Policy]] -* [[Ministry of Emergencies (Ukraine)|Ministry of Emergencies]] +* [[Ministry of Emergencies (Ukraine)|Ministry of Emergencies]] * [[Ministry of Infrastructure (Ukraine)|Ministry of Infrastructure]] * [[Ministry of Justice (Ukraine)|Ministry of Justice]] * [[Ministry of Finance (Ukraine)|Ministry of Finance]] @@ -88,10 +88,10 @@ ==Current Cabinet== {{main|First Azarov Government}} -The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010) The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government. Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government stayed on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010) A new coalition had to be formed 30 days and a government within 60 (days from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] was to be held. [[Azarov Government#Controversy and criticism|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010) 235 deputies from the 450-member Verkhovna Rada signed the coalition agreement.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010) On March 11, 2010, the Verkhovna Rada approved the structure of the current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.[http://unian.net/eng/news/news-366951.html VR approved structure of Cabinet of Ministers (update)], [[UNIAN]] (March 11, 2010) On October 1, 2010 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] overturned the 2004 Constitutional Amendments, considering them unconstitutional.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 1, 2010)[http://www.finchannel.com/Main_News/Ukraine/72720_Rada_Approves_Cancellation_Of_Rule_That_Bans_Deputies_From_Switching_Factions_/ Rada Approves Cancellation Of Rule That Bans Deputies From Switching Factions], [[FINANCIAL]] (October 8, 2010) The motion was filed on July 14 of that year by the representatives of the [[Azarov Government]]. On December 9, 2010 the [[President of Ukraine]] reloaded a new government.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/12/10/5660088/ Yanukovych reloaded a new government (Ukrainian Pravda, December 10, 2010)] According to the decree, the number of ministries was reduced from 20 to 16 and the number of cabinet employees (1,174 people at the time) is to be more than halved.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93136/ Government to reduce number of its secretariat employees by 50%], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 18, 2010) +The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010) The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government. Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government stayed on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010) A new coalition had to be formed 30 days and a government within 60 (days from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] was to be held. On December 9, 2010 the [[President of Ukraine]] reloaded a new government.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/12/10/5660088/ Yanukovych reloaded a new government (Ukrainian Pravda, December 10, 2010)] According to the decree, the number of ministries was reduced from 20 to 16 and the number of cabinet employees (1,174 people at the time) is to be more than halved.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93136/ Government to reduce number of its secretariat employees by 50%], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 18, 2010) ===Current composition=== -{{Template:Azarov Government}} +{{Azarov Government}} ==References== {{reflist}} @@ -105,6 +105,7 @@ {{Ukraine topics}} {{Types of government minister}} +{{DEFAULTSORT:Cabinet Of Ministers Of Ukraine}} [[Category:Government of Ukraine]] [[Category:National cabinets|Ukraine]] [[Category:Cabinets of Ukraine| ]]

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -12,7 +12,7 @@
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
 The duties of the cabinet of ministers are described in the [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 116|Article 116]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].
 ;Authority
-The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subjects to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act. (see [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 117|Article 117]])
+The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act. (see [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 117|Article 117]])
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
 Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] (with amendments of 2004) a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (rather than by individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament ([[Verkhovna Rada]]), a "coalition of parliamentary factions" (Ukrainian: Коаліція парламентських партій).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010, however, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the constitutional amendments of 2004 illegal, thus abolishing the principal of coalition creation in the parliament ([[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]).
llm_output:
Changed "subjects" to "subject" in the context of normative legal acts.

Not Weaponised – The change is a grammatical correction and does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives.

 The '''Cabinet of Ukraine''' (also called the '''Cabinet of Ministers''', {{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government.

At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98).

 The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The [[Azarov Government|13th and latest Cabinet]] was chosen on On March 11, 2010 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=azahere/>
 
 Parts of Cabinet meetings are broadcasted live on [[Ukrainian TV]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67177/ First National Channel to broadcast governmental meetings], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 19, 2010)</ref>

People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007) A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010) On October 1, 2010, however, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the constitutional amendments of 2004 illegal, thus abolishing the principal of coalition creation in the parliament ([[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]). -The Prime Minister, following his appointment, nominates other members of the Cabinet (19 ministers) for approval by the Verkhovna Rada,[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/49986/ Government approves draft law on cabinet according to which president appoints premier], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (October 5, 2010) except for the Minister of the Foreign Affairs and one of Defense, who are both nominated by the President. The President can dismiss any government minister or deputy minister unilaterally at any time.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/ Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 13, 2010)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85342/ Parliament adopts new law on cabinet complying with 1996 Constitution], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 7, 2010) Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside of working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit. ==List of current ministries== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" +|- ! On December 9, 2010 the [[President of Ukraine]] reloaded a new government.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/12/10/5660088/ Yanukovych reloaded a new government (Ukrainian Pravda, December 10, 2010)] According to the decree, the number of ministries was reduced from 20 to 16 and the number of cabinet employees (1,174 people at the time) is to be more than halved.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93136/ Government to reduce number of its secretariat employees by 50%], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 18, 2010) ===Current composition=== {{Azarov Government}}

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

@@ -12,8 +12,6 @@
 ==Authority==
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
 The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subjects to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.
-
-On May 13, 2010 [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Mykola Azarov]] claimed that ninety percent of decisions taken by the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] had not been implemented in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66620/ Azarov slams execution of government resolutions in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2010)</ref>
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
 Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] (with amendments of 2004) a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (rather than by individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament ([[Verkhovna Rada]]), a "coalition of parliamentary factions" (Ukrainian: Коаліція парламентських партій).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice], Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (April 12, 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 12, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010, however, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the constitutional amendments of 2004 illegal, thus abolishing the principal of coalition creation in the parliament ([[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]).
comment: /* Authority */ related to the office of prime minister
llm_output:
Removed a statement regarding Prime Minister Mykola Azarov's claim about the implementation of decisions by the second Tymoshenko Government.

Not Weaponised – The removed content does not contain any language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage. It is a factual statement about political actions in Ukraine.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 The '''Cabinet of Ukraine''' (also called the '''Cabinet of Ministers''', {{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]}}</ref> and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government. 
 
 ==Scope==
-The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98).
+The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). There also is the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine that used to head by the Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, but eventually lost the ministerial portfolio. Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
 [[File:FEMEN activists demand posts for women.jpg|left|thumb|Police in front of the Cabinet during a protest in 2010.]]
 The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The [[Azarov Government|13th and latest Cabinet]] was chosen on On March 11, 2010 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=azahere/>
llm_output:
Change Description: Added additional information about the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine and its structural components.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change provides factual information about the Ukrainian government structure without employing any loaded or politically charged language.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). There also is the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine that used to head by the Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, but eventually lost the ministerial portfolio. Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.

 {{main|First Azarov Government}}
 The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name="endSTG">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref><ref name="fall">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government. Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government stayed on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name="TychoPM">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref><ref name="TychoPM"/> A new coalition had to be formed 30 days and a government within 60 (days from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] was to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> [[Azarov Government#Controversy and criticism|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member Verkhovna Rada signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> On March 11, 2010, the Verkhovna Rada approved the structure of the current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.<ref name="azahere">[http://unian.net/eng/news/news-366951.html VR approved structure of Cabinet of Ministers (update)], [[UNIAN]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] overturned the 2004 Constitutional Amendments, considering them unconstitutional.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 1, 2010)</ref><ref name="FINANCIAL">[http://www.finchannel.com/Main_News/Ukraine/72720_Rada_Approves_Cancellation_Of_Rule_That_Bans_Deputies_From_Switching_Factions_/ Rada Approves Cancellation Of Rule That Bans Deputies From Switching Factions], [[FINANCIAL]] (October 8, 2010)</ref> The motion was filed on July 14 of that year by the representatives of the [[Azarov Government]]. On December 9, 2010 the [[President of Ukraine]] reloaded a new government.<ref>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/12/10/5660088/ Yanukovych reloaded a new government (Ukrainian Pravda, December 10, 2010)]</ref> According to the decree, the number of ministries was reduced from 20 to 16 and the number of cabinet employees (1,174 people at the time) is to be more than halved.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93136/ Government to reduce number of its secretariat employees by 50%], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 18, 2010)</ref>

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

{{stub}}

[[category:Ukraine]]
[[category:Ukrainian government]]
[[category:Ukrainian politics]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@
 The Cabinet consists of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers.
 
 ==Scope==
-The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). There also is the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine that used to head by the Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, but eventually lost the ministerial portfolio. Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
+The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, three<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/ Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers]</ref> Vice-Prime Ministers, and other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). There also is the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine that used to head by the Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, but eventually lost the ministerial portfolio. Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
 
 Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order.
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a reference to the number of Vice-Prime Ministers, specifically changing "several Vice-Prime Ministers" to "three Vice-Prime Ministers" and including a citation. 

Not Weaponised. The change is factual and pertains to the structure of the Ukrainian government without invoking any contentious cultural or political narratives.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

[[category:Ukraine]]
[[category:Ukrainian government]]
[[category:Ukrainian politics]]
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -6,6 +6,9 @@
 
 ==Scope==
 The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). There also is the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine that used to head by the Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, but eventually lost the ministerial portfolio. Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
+
+Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order.
+
 The Cabinet is steered by the Prime Minister, chosen from the parliament with the President's formal proposal. The [[Azarov Government|13th and latest Cabinet]] was chosen on On March 11, 2010 and is headed by Ukraine's Prime Minister [[Mykola Azarov]].<ref name=azahere/>
 
 Parts of Cabinet meetings are broadcasted live on [[Ukrainian TV]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67177/ First National Channel to broadcast governmental meetings], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 19, 2010)</ref>
llm_output:
Added information about the qualifications and rights of government members, specifically mentioning that they must be citizens of Ukraine, have the right to vote, possess higher education, and know the state language (Ukrainian).

Not Weaponised. The changes provide factual information about the qualifications for government members without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

--- +++ @@ -2,7 +2,9 @@ [[File:Kiev Cabinet of Ministers.jpg|thumb|225px|The building of the Cabinet of Ministers.
It is locally known as [[Budynok Uryadu]].]] [[File:Government Building.JPG|225px|right|The building of the Cabinet of Ministers]] {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}} -The '''Cabinet of Ukraine''' (also called the '''Cabinet of Ministers''', {{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archivedate = March 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} and serves as the [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] of government since 1917 carrying various names in the past. The Cabinet consists of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers. +The '''Cabinet of Ukraine''' (also called the '''Cabinet of Ministers''', {{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archivedate = March 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} also referred to as the Government of Ukraine (''Uryad Ukrayiny''). The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Empire]] - General Secretariat. + +The Cabinet consists of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers. ==Scope== The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, several Vice-Prime Ministers, the Minister of the Cabinet and many other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). There also is the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine that used to head by the Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, but eventually lost the ministerial portfolio. Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of the phrase "also referred to as the Government of Ukraine (''Uryad Ukrayiny''). The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Empire]] - General Secretariat." This addition provides historical context regarding the establishment of the Ukrainian government and its connection to the Russian Empire.

Weaponised. The inclusion of the phrase "regional government of the [[Russian Empire]]" can be interpreted as an attempt to frame Ukraine's historical governance in a way that emphasizes its ties to Russia, which may serve to undermine Ukraine's sovereignty and cultural identity in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions.

 The '''Cabinet of Ukraine''' (also called the '''Cabinet of Ministers''', {{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archivedate = March 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> also referred to as the Government of Ukraine (''Uryad Ukrayiny''). The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Empire]] - General Secretariat. 
 
-The Cabinet consists of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers.
+The Cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers.
 
 ==Scope==
 The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control and being held accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian [[parliament]]). It consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, three<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/ Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers]</ref> Vice-Prime Ministers, and other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one point of time there also was an institute of "state ministries" that was majorly abolished on February 25, 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). There also is the Secretariat of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine that used to head by the Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine, but eventually lost the ministerial portfolio. Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.

Changed "The Cabinet consists of several ministries" to "The Cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of several ministries".

Not Weaponised. The change is a rephrasing for clarity and does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers.

-==Current Cabinet==
+==Cabinet's party assignments==
 {{main|First Azarov Government}}
 The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) dismissed the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] on March 3, 2010.<ref name="endSTG">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/ Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 3, 2010)</ref><ref name="fall">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60822/ Factbox: Long road to a new Ukrainian coalition and government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref> The [[Ukrainian Constitution]] stipulates that before a new government is endorsed, the outgoing Cabinet stays on as a caretaker government. Thus the minister from the second Tymoshenko Government stayed on as [[Acting (law)|acting]] ministers.<ref name=fall/><ref name="TychoPM">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60917/ Update: Acting Premier Tymoshenko to take a vacation, Turchynov to head government], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 1, 2010)</ref><ref name="TychoPM"/> A new coalition had to be formed 30 days and a government within 60 (days from March 3, 2010), or a [[Next Ukrainian parliamentary election|snap parliamentary election]] was to be held.<ref name=endSTG/> [[Azarov Government#Controversy and criticism|Amid controversy]] Ukrainian lawmakers formed a new coalition on March 11, 2010 which included [[Bloc Lytvyn]], [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Party of regions]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61450/ Ukrainian parliament creates new coalition], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> 235 deputies from the 450-member Verkhovna Rada signed the coalition agreement.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/61441/ Update: Former finance minister nominated as Ukraine prime minister], [[Kyiv Post]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> On March 11, 2010, the Verkhovna Rada approved the structure of the current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.<ref name="azahere">[http://unian.net/eng/news/news-366951.html VR approved structure of Cabinet of Ministers (update)], [[UNIAN]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> On October 1, 2010 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] overturned the 2004 Constitutional Amendments, considering them unconstitutional.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 1, 2010)</ref><ref name="FINANCIAL">[http://www.finchannel.com/Main_News/Ukraine/72720_Rada_Approves_Cancellation_Of_Rule_That_Bans_Deputies_From_Switching_Factions_/ Rada Approves Cancellation Of Rule That Bans Deputies From Switching Factions], [[FINANCIAL]] (October 8, 2010)</ref> The motion was filed on July 14 of that year by the representatives of the [[Azarov Government]]. On December 9, 2010 the [[President of Ukraine]] reloaded a new government.<ref>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/12/10/5660088/ Yanukovych reloaded a new government (Ukrainian Pravda, December 10, 2010)]</ref> According to the decree, the number of ministries was reduced from 20 to 16 and the number of cabinet employees (1,174 people at the time) is to be more than halved.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93136/ Government to reduce number of its secretariat employees by 50%], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 18, 2010)</ref>
llm_output:
Changed the section title from "Current Cabinet" to "Cabinet's party assignments".

Not Weaponised – The change is a straightforward title adjustment that does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Empire]] - General Secretariat. +The '''Cabinet of Ukraine''' (also called the '''Cabinet of Ministers''', {{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archivedate = March 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} also referred to as the Government of Ukraine (''Uryad Ukrayiny''). The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Republic]] - General Secretariat. The Cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers. The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] ensures the operations of the cabinet.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

It is locally known as [[Budynok Uryadu]].]] [[File:Government Building.JPG|thumb|225px|The building of the Cabinet of Ministers]] {{coord|50|26|52.0|N|30|32|1.4|E|type:landmark_region:UA|display=title}} -The '''Cabinet of Ukraine''' (also called the '''Cabinet of Ministers''', {{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archivedate = March 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} also referred to as the Government of Ukraine (''Uryad Ukrayiny''). The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Republic]] - General Secretariat. +The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archivedate = March 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} also referred to as the Government of Ukraine (''Uryad Ukrayiny''). The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Republic]] - General Secretariat. The Cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers. The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] ensures the operations of the cabinet.

The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Republic]] - General Secretariat. +The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України}}, Kabinet ministriv Ukrayiny) is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in [[Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116|title=Article 116|accessdate=2007-12-23|work=[[Wikisource]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archivedate = March 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} also referred to as the '''Government of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Уряд України}}, ''Uryad Ukrayiny''). The first modern national government of Ukraine was established in 1917 as the regional government of the [[Russian Republic]] - General Secretariat. The Cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of several [[Ukrainian ministries|ministries]] that are headed by their respective minister. The Prime Minister of Ukraine presides over the Cabinet and is assisted by his First Vice Premier and other Vice Premier ministers. The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] ensures the operations of the cabinet.

Changed the phrasing of the Ukrainian government name from "Uryad Ukrayiny" to "Уряд України" and added the transliteration "Kabinet ministriv Ukrayiny".

Not Weaponised – The changes are primarily linguistic and do not introduce any politically charged narratives or weaponised terms.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]
