The members of Cabinet and deputy ministers may be present at the sessions of the parliament and participate in discussions. Every year no later than 15 September the Cabinet submits a bill on the State Budget of Ukraine to the Verkhovna Rada.
+The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act. (see [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 117|Article 117]]) The Cabinet also possesses the power of [[legislative initiative]] and may introduce its own [[Bill (proposed law)|bill]]s to the ''Verkhovna Rada''. The members of Cabinet and deputy ministers may be present at the sessions of the parliament and participate in discussions. Every year no later than 15 September the Cabinet submits a bill on the State Budget of Ukraine to the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
 
 The sessions of the Cabinet are considered plenipotentiary if more than a half of the Cabinet's members participate in them. In case if a minister cannot participate at the sessions they may be replaced by a deputy with a consultative capacity. On propositions of other members of the Cabinet a consultative capacity may be awarded to other participants who allowed at the sessions of the Cabinet. Over the sessions presides the Prime Minister of Ukraine, while in his(hers) absent – the First Vice Prime Minister.

''[https://web.archive.org/web/20200924142511/http://academy.gov.ua/ej/ej13/txts/Zapadynchuk.pdf Optimization of the central executive authorities in the context of administrative reform]''. [[National Academy for Public Administration]]</ref> Until the adaptation of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] in 1996, the government of Ukraine was ruled by the 1978 Constitution of Ukraine (the Ukrainian SSR).<ref name=Zapadynchuk/> Also, the 1978 Constitution ruled that the [[President of Ukraine]] (an office created in 1991) is a head of state and a head of government (executive power) (Article 114-1).<ref>The 1978 [https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/888-09#Text Constitution of Ukraine]. [[Verkhovna Rada]].</ref><ref name=Zapadynchuk/> At the same time, the government headed by Prime Minister ''de facto'' remained independent and detached from the President, a state institution which had to function governed by its own programme.<ref name=Zapadynchuk/>
 
 ==Duties and authority==
 [[File:Kiev Cabinet of Ministers.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Government Building, Kyiv|Government Building]], 12/2, [[Hrushevsky Street (Kyiv)|Hrushevsky Street]], [[Kyiv]], [[Ukraine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/en/photogallery/gallerylist?gGroupId=12958356|title=Official CMU website. Building address.|date=March 2017}}</ref>]]The duties of the cabinet of ministers are described in the [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 116|Article 116]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]]. Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order. Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit. In case if a [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] was appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine they resign as a member of parliament and their letter of resignation is reviewed immediately at the next session of the [[Ukrainian parliament]].

[[Vitold Fokin]] was approved as the first [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]].
 
-The Cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of the Cabinet's "presidium" composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and their Vice Prime Ministers as well as other ministers who participate and vote on sessions of the Cabinet. The Prime Minister presides over the Cabinet. Some Vice Prime Ministers may be appointed as the first vice prime ministers. Unlike the Soviet period of the government when presidium was actually a functioning institution, the current government presidium is nominal and vice prime ministers do not have much advantage over other ministers. All government decisions are being voted for and adopted at the sessions of the Cabinet by ministers only or heads of central offices of executive authority with ministerial status. The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] ensures the operations of the cabinet, while the [[National Agency of Ukraine for Civil Service]] provides human resources of government officials.
+The Sweet Cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of the Cabinet's "presidium" composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and their Vice Prime Ministers as well as other ministers who participate and vote on sessions of the Cabinet. The Prime Minister presides over the Cabinet. Some Vice Prime Ministers may be appointed as the first vice prime ministers. Unlike the Soviet period of the government when presidium was actually a functioning institution, the current government presidium is nominal and vice prime ministers do not have much advantage over other ministers. All government decisions are being voted for and adopted at the sessions of the Cabinet by ministers only or heads of central offices of executive authority with ministerial status. The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] ensures the operations of the cabinet, while the [[National Agency of Ukraine for Civil Service]] provides human resources of government officials. Sweet Cabinet, good times never felt so good
 
 The basic unit of government administration in Ukraine is a central office of executive authority (central executive office) which may be granted ministerial status. Each such central office of executive authority is chaired by its head (''holova''). Many central offices of executive authority without ministerial status may be part of a government ministry, while others function separately or support either the [[President of Ukraine]] or the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Parliament). Central offices of executive authority without ministerial status are designated either as services, agencies, or inspections. Selected central offices of executive authority are granted a "special status". Only very few central executive offices are designated as funds, committees or otherwise.

This could be interpreted as an attempt to diminish the legitimacy of the Ukrainian government, which aligns with narratives that may be used to weaponize cultural heritage by framing state institutions in a derogatory manner.

**Conclusion:** Weaponised

+==Scope==
+The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. Each ministry is in charge of other government sub-departments. There are three basic types of government sub-departments known as "central offices (organs) of executive authority": services, agencies, inspections. Beside the basic government sub-departments there also other government sub-departments which were granted a special status. Among such sub-departments there are various government committees, government commissions, government funds, and other institutions. Sub-departments may be elevated to ministerial status by their reorganization and, vice versa, government ministries may degraded to sub-departments (e.g. Ministry of Emergencies was degraded to a sub-department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs).
+
+The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of, and is held accountable to, the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukrainian parliament). The Cabinet consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, three<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/|title=Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers}}</ref> Vice-Prime Ministers, and other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one time, there also was an institute of "state ministries", this institute being abolished on 25 February 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] (or Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers) supports the effective operation of the government.<ref name=MAG2KP241212>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yanukovych-is-appointing-new-cabinet-of-ministers-318086.html Yanukovych appoints new Cabinet of Ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (24 December 2007)</ref> Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
+
+===Public relations===
+Parts of Cabinet meetings are broadcast live on [[Ukrainian TV]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67177/ First National Channel to broadcast governmental meetings], [[Kyiv Post]] (19 May 2010)</ref>
+
+Since August 2016, Ukrainians can sign and submit [[electronic petition]]s to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine "to (assist with) the formation of the priorities of state policy and management decision-making".<ref name=opU29816>[http://www.unian.info/politics/1491296-ukrainians-can-submit-e-petitions-to-sabinet-from-aug-29.html Ukrainians can submit e-petitions to Cabinet from Aug 29], [[UNIAN]] (29 August 2016)</ref> To be considered, the petition must get at least 25,000 votes three months from the date of publication.<ref name=opU29816/>
+
+===Reforms and "optimizations"===
+According to Oleksandr Zapadynchuk, the process of establishing an administrative system in an already independent Ukraine started in the spring of 1991 when the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine (in place of the Council of Ministers of the [[Ukrainian SSR]]) was created, with new members of the government being appointed, as well as a new government office being formed.<ref name=Zapadynchuk>Zapadinchuk, O.P. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20200924142511/http://academy.gov.ua/ej/ej13/txts/Zapadynchuk.pdf Optimization of the central executive authorities in the context of administrative reform]''. [[National Academy for Public Administration]]</ref> Until the adaptation of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] in 1996, the government of Ukraine was ruled by the 1978 Constitution of Ukraine (the Ukrainian SSR).<ref name=Zapadynchuk/> Also, the 1978 Constitution ruled that the [[President of Ukraine]] (an office created in 1991) is a head of state and a head of government (executive power) (Article 114-1).<ref>The 1978 [https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/888-09#Text Constitution of Ukraine]. [[Verkhovna Rada]].</ref><ref name=Zapadynchuk/> At the same time, the government headed by Prime Minister ''de facto'' remained independent and detached from the President, a state institution which had to function governed by its own programme.<ref name=Zapadynchuk/>
 
 ==Duties and authority==
 [[File:Kiev Cabinet of Ministers.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Government Building, Kyiv|Government Building]], 12/2, [[Hrushevsky Street (Kyiv)|Hrushevsky Street]], [[Kyiv]], [[Ukraine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/en/photogallery/gallerylist?gGroupId=12958356|title=Official CMU website. Building address.|date=March 2017}}</ref>]]The duties of the Cabinet of Ministers are described in [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 116|Article 116]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]]. Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order. Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit. In case if a [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] was appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine they resign as a member of parliament and their letter of resignation is reviewed immediately at the next session of the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukrainian parliament).

Change: Added a new section titled "Scope" and included detailed information about the structure and responsibilities of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The content appears to be factual and administrative in nature, focusing on the structure and functions of the Ukrainian government without employing any weaponisation terms or narratives.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

 The composition of Cabinet is determined by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]] on the petition of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] (with exception of Minister of Defence and Minister of Foreign Affairs, which candidates are proposed by the President). The legislation on Labor and State Service do not cover regulations of Cabinet's members. Positions of Cabinet of Ministers are political and are regulated by the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and the Law of Ukraine on the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.
 
-The Verkhovna Rada terminates the powers of [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|members of parliament]] appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-terminates-mandates-of-yatsenyuk-eight-members-of-parliament-appointed-ministers-373866.html Rada terminates mandates of Yatsenyuk, eight members of parliament appointed ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)</ref>
+The ''Verkhovna Rada'' terminates the powers of [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|members of parliament]] appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-terminates-mandates-of-yatsenyuk-eight-members-of-parliament-appointed-ministers-373866.html Rada terminates mandates of Yatsenyuk, eight members of parliament appointed ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)</ref>
 ===2004 Constitutional amendments===
 The '''2004 Constitutional amendments''' are also erroneously known as the 2004 Constitution of Ukraine. The following amendments were procedurally adopted however as amendments rather than as constitution which requires approval of 2/3 parliament.

 ==Appointment and dismissal==
-The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's parliament) has five days to approve the Prime Minister after the President proposes a candidate.<ref name=KP31212DMbB>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/azarov-out-for-now-or-out-for-good-as-prime-minister-317085.html Azarov out for now or out for good as prime minister?], [[Kyiv Post]] (3 December 2012)</ref> A vote in Parliament is required to approve or dismiss any government minister.<ref name="voxukraineUsoge">[https://voxukraine.org/cards/pravlinnya/index-en.html#three Political Explainer: Ukraine’s System of Government], [[VoxUkraine]]</ref> The President or one-third of [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|members of parliament]] can initiate a vote of no confidence, but only once in a parliament session.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://zakon3.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/794-18|title=Про Кабінет Міністрів України}}</ref>
+The ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukraine's parliament) has five days to approve the Prime Minister after the President proposes a candidate.<ref name=KP31212DMbB>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/azarov-out-for-now-or-out-for-good-as-prime-minister-317085.html Azarov out for now or out for good as prime minister?], [[Kyiv Post]] (3 December 2012)</ref> A vote in Parliament is required to approve or dismiss any government minister.<ref name="voxukraineUsoge">[https://voxukraine.org/cards/pravlinnya/index-en.html#three Political Explainer: Ukraine’s System of Government], [[VoxUkraine]]</ref> The President or one-third of [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|members of parliament]] can initiate a vote of no confidence, but only once in a parliament session.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://zakon3.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/794-18|title=Про Кабінет Міністрів України}}</ref>
 
 The entire Cabinet has to be dismissed following the Prime Minister's resignation.<ref name=KP31212DMA>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/nsdc-secretary-sees-azarov-as-likely-candidate-for-premiership-317089.html NSDC secretary sees Azarov as likely candidate for premiership], [[Kyiv Post]] (3 December 2012)</ref> But a Cabinet's resignation cannot be considered within a year of the Cabinet's approval of its program of activities, meaning a Cabinet dismissal can not done in its first year of existence.<ref name="7237561Tymoshenko">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/01/16/7237561/ Tymoshenko wants change of power: "Let them return to their 95s"], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (16 January 2020)</ref>

Not Weaponised – The change is purely stylistic and does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
 ==Scope==
 The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. Each ministry is in charge of other government sub-departments. There are three basic types of government sub-departments known as "central offices (organs) of executive authority": services, agencies, inspections. Beside the basic government sub-departments there also other government sub-departments which were granted a special status. Among such sub-departments there are various government committees, government commissions, government funds, and other institutions. Sub-departments may be elevated to ministerial status by their reorganization and, vice versa, government ministries may degraded to sub-departments (e.g. Ministry of Emergencies was degraded to a sub-department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs).
 
-The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of, and is held accountable to, the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukrainian parliament). At one time, there also was an institute of "state ministries", this institute being abolished on 25 February 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). -Since August 2016, Ukrainians can sign and submit [[electronic petition]]s to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine "to (assist with) the formation of the priorities of state policy and management decision-making".<ref name=opU29816>[http://www.unian.info/politics/1491296-ukrainians-can-submit-e-petitions-to-sabinet-from-aug-29.html Ukrainians can submit e-petitions to Cabinet from Aug 29], [[UNIAN]] (29 August 2016)</ref> To be considered, the petition must get at least 25,000 votes three months from the date of publication.<ref name=opU29816/>
-
-===Reforms and "optimizations"===
-According to Oleksandr Zapadynchuk, the process of establishing an administrative system in an already independent Ukraine started in the spring of 1991 when the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine (in place of the Council of Ministers of the [[Ukrainian SSR]]) was created, with new members of the government being appointed, as well as a new government office being formed.<ref name=Zapadynchuk>Zapadinchuk, O.P. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20200924142511/http://academy.gov.ua/ej/ej13/txts/Zapadynchuk.pdf Optimization of the central executive authorities in the context of administrative reform]''. [[National Academy for Public Administration]]</ref> Until the adaptation of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] in 1996, the government of Ukraine was ruled by the 1978 Constitution of Ukraine (the Ukrainian SSR).<ref name=Zapadynchuk/> Also, the 1978 Constitution ruled that the [[President of Ukraine]] (an office created in 1991) is a head of state and a head of government (executive power) (Article 114-1).<ref>The 1978 [https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/888-09#Text Constitution of Ukraine]. [[Verkhovna Rada]].</ref><ref name=Zapadynchuk/> At the same time, the government headed by Prime Minister ''de facto'' remained independent and detached from the President, a state institution which had to function governed by its own programme.<ref name=Zapadynchuk/>

 ==Duties and authority==
 [[File:Kiev Cabinet of Ministers.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Government Building, Kyiv|Government Building]], 12/2, [[Hrushevsky Street (Kyiv)|Hrushevsky Street]], [[Kyiv]], [[Ukraine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/en/photogallery/gallerylist?gGroupId=12958356|title=Official CMU website. Building address.|date=March 2017}}</ref>]]The duties of the Cabinet of Ministers are described in [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 116|Article 116]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]]. Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order. Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit. In case if a [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] was appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine they resign as a member of parliament and their letter of resignation is reviewed immediately at the next session of the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukrainian parliament).

Not Weaponised – The change is administrative in nature, focusing on the organization of government without invoking any cultural or political narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

The Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (or Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers) supports the effective operation of the government.<ref name=MAG2KP241212>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yanukovych-is-appointing-new-cabinet-of-ministers-318086.html Yanukovych appoints new Cabinet of Ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (24 December 2007)</ref> Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
+The Cabinet is responsible to the President of Ukraine and is under the control of, and is held accountable to, the ''Verkhovna Rada''. The Cabinet consists of the Prime Minister, the First Vice-Prime Minister, three<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/|title=Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers|date=13 October 2010 }}</ref> Vice-Prime Ministers, and other Ministers, who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one time, there also was an institute of "state ministries", this institute being abolished on 25 February 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). The Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (or Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers) supports the effective operation of the government.<ref name=MAG2KP241212>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yanukovych-is-appointing-new-cabinet-of-ministers-318086.html Yanukovych appoints new Cabinet of Ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (24 December 2007)</ref> Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
 
 ===Public relations===
 Parts of Cabinet meetings are broadcast live on [[Television in Ukraine|Ukrainian TV]].<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67177/ First National Channel to broadcast governmental meetings], [[Kyiv Post]] (19 May 2010)</ref>

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

 Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (rather than by individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament, a "coalition of parliamentary factions" (Ukrainian: Коаліція парламентських партій).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014165841/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html |date=14 October 2008 }}, Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (12 April 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by members of parliament.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (12 February 2010)</ref> On 1 October 2010, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] declared the [[Constitution of Ukraine#2004 and 2010 amendments and 2014 return to 2004 amendments|constitutional amendments of 2004]] illegal, thus abolishing the principle of coalition creation in the parliament.<ref>[http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 Summary to the Decision of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine No. 20-rp/2010 dated 30 September 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326012947/http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 |date=26 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (1 October 2010)</ref> In February 2014 the parliament passed a law that reinstated the 2004 amendments of the constitution.<ref name="bt2004UCIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/191727.html Ukrainian parliament reinstates 2004 Constitution], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (21 February 2014)</ref> Three days later they also terminated the powers of five judges of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine appointed from the parliament's quota, for violating their oath.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/192520.html Rada dismisses Constitutional Court judges appointed from its quota, proposes acting president and congress of judges dismiss the rest], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (24 February 2014)</ref>

 [[File:Kiev Cabinet of Ministers.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Government Building, Kyiv|Government Building]], 12/2, [[Hrushevsky Street (Kyiv)|Hrushevsky Street]], [[Kyiv]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/en/photogallery/gallerylist?gGroupId=12958356|title=Official CMU website. Building address.|date=March 2017}}</ref>]]The duties of the Cabinet of Ministers are described in [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 116|Article 116]] of the Constitution of Ukraine. Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order. Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit. In case if a [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] was appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine they resign as a member of parliament and their letter of resignation is reviewed immediately at the next session of the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
 
-At the sessions of the Cabinet may participate the President of Ukraine or their [[Representatives of the President of Ukraine|representative]]. During the plenary sessions of the ''Verkhovna Rada'', the People's Deputies of Ukraine have the ''Time of questions to the Government'' during which the whole Cabinet participates and answers to all queries of members of the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
+At the sessions of the Cabinet, the President of Ukraine or their designee may participate. During the plenary sessions of the ''Verkhovna Rada'', the People's Deputies of Ukraine have the ''Time of questions to the Government'' during which the whole Cabinet participates and answers to all queries of members of the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
 
 ;Authority
 The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act. (see [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 117|Article 117]]) The Cabinet also possesses the power of [[Right of initiative (legislative)|legislative initiative]] and may introduce its own [[Bill (law)|bills]] to the ''Verkhovna Rada''. The members of Cabinet and deputy ministers may be present at the sessions of the parliament and participate in discussions. Every year no later than 15 September the Cabinet submits a bill on the State Budget of Ukraine to the ''Verkhovna Rada''.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

 The ''Verkhovna Rada'' terminates the powers of members of parliament appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-terminates-mandates-of-yatsenyuk-eight-members-of-parliament-appointed-ministers-373866.html Rada terminates mandates of Yatsenyuk, eight members of parliament appointed ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)</ref>
 
 ===2004 constitutional amendments===
-The '''2004 constitutional amendments''' are also erroneously known as the 2004 Constitution of Ukraine. The following amendments were procedurally adopted however as amendments rather than as constitution which requires approval of 2/3 parliament.
+The '''2004 constitutional amendments''' are also erroneously known as the 2004 Constitution of Ukraine. The following amendments were procedurally adopted however as amendments rather than as constitution which requires a two-thirds majority approval from Parliament.
 
-Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (rather than by individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament, a "coalition of parliamentary factions" (Ukrainian: Коаліція парламентських партій).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014165841/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html |date=14 October 2008 }}, Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (12 April 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by members of parliament.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (12 February 2010)</ref> On 1 October 2010, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] declared the [[Constitution of Ukraine#2004 and 2010 amendments and 2014 return to 2004 amendments|constitutional amendments of 2004]] illegal, thus abolishing the principle of coalition creation in the parliament.<ref>[http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 Summary to the Decision of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine No. 20-rp/2010 dated 30 September 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326012947/http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 |date=26 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (1 October 2010)</ref> In February 2014 the parliament passed a law that reinstated the 2004 amendments of the constitution.<ref name="bt2004UCIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/191727.html Ukrainian parliament reinstates 2004 Constitution], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (21 February 2014)</ref> Three days later they also terminated the powers of five judges of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine appointed from the parliament's quota, for violating their oath.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/192520.html Rada dismisses Constitutional Court judges appointed from its quota, proposes acting president and congress of judges dismiss the rest], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (24 February 2014)</ref>
+Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (rather than by individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament, a "coalition of parliamentary factions" (Ukrainian: Коаліція парламентських партій).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014165841/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html |date=14 October 2008 }}, Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (12 April 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by members of parliament.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (12 February 2010)</ref> On 1 October 2010, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] declared the [[Constitution of Ukraine#2004 and 2010 amendments and 2014 return to 2004 amendments|constitutional amendments of 2004]] illegal, thus abolishing the principle of coalition creation in the parliament.<ref>[http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 Summary to the Decision of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine No. 20-rp/2010 dated 30 September 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326012947/http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 |date=26 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (1 October 2010)</ref> On 21 February 2014 the parliament passed a law that reinstated the 2004 amendments of the constitution.<ref name="bt2004UCIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/191727.html Ukrainian parliament reinstates 2004 Constitution], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (21 February 2014)</ref> Three days later, they also terminated the powers of five judges of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine appointed from the parliament's quota, for violating their oath.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/192520.html Rada dismisses Constitutional Court judges appointed from its quota, proposes acting president and congress of judges dismiss the rest], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (24 February 2014)</ref>

 The current Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine is the [[Shmyhal Government]] that was formed on 4 March 2020, led by [[Denys Shmyhal]].<ref name="btkpBermetHasty">{{cite news |last1=Talant |first1=Bermet |title=Hasty government reshuffle sows disquiet at home, abroad |publisher=Kyiv Post |date=6 March 2020 |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/hasty-government-reshuffle-sows-disquiet-at-home-abroad.html}}</ref>
 
 ==Scope==
-The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. Each ministry is in charge of other government sub-departments. There are three basic types of government sub-departments known as "central offices (organs) of executive authority": services, agencies, inspections. Beside the basic government sub-departments there also other government sub-departments which were granted a special status. Among such sub-departments there are various government committees, government commissions, government funds, and other institutions. Sub-departments may be elevated to ministerial status by their reorganization and, vice versa, government ministries may degraded to sub-departments (e.g. Ministry of Emergencies was degraded to a sub-department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs).
+The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. Each ministry is in charge of other government sub-departments. There are three basic types of government sub-departments known as "central offices (organs) of executive authority": services, agencies, inspections. Beside the basic government sub-departments there also other government sub-departments which were granted a special status. Among such sub-departments there are various government committees, government commissions, government funds, and other institutions. Sub-departments may be elevated to ministerial status by their reorganisation and, vice versa, government ministries may degraded to sub-departments (e.g. Ministry of Emergencies was degraded to a sub-department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs).
 
 The Cabinet is responsible to the President of Ukraine and is under the control of, and is held accountable to, the ''Verkhovna Rada''. The Cabinet consists of the Prime Minister, the First Vice-Prime Minister, three<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/|title=Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers|date=13 October 2010 }}</ref> Vice-Prime Ministers, and other Ministers, who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one time, there also was an institute of "state ministries", this institute being abolished on 25 February 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). The Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (or Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers) supports the effective operation of the government.<ref name=MAG2KP241212>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yanukovych-is-appointing-new-cabinet-of-ministers-318086.html Yanukovych appoints new Cabinet of Ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (24 December 2007)</ref> Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
 
@@ -43,7 +43,7 @@
 According to Oleksandr Zapadynchuk, the process of establishing an administrative system in an already independent Ukraine started in the spring of 1991 when the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine (in place of the Council of Ministers of the Ukrainian SSR) was created, with new members of the government being appointed, as well as a new government office being formed.<ref name=Zapadynchuk>Zapadinchuk, O.P. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20200924142511/http://academy.gov.ua/ej/ej13/txts/Zapadynchuk.pdf Optimization of the central executive authorities in the context of administrative reform]''. [[National Academy for Public Administration]]</ref> Until the adaptation of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] in 1996, the government of Ukraine was ruled by the 1978 Constitution of Ukraine (the Ukrainian SSR).<ref name=Zapadynchuk/> Also, the 1978 Constitution ruled that the President of Ukraine (an office created in 1991) is a head of state and a head of government (executive power) (Article 114-1).<ref>The 1978 [https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/888-09#Text Constitution of Ukraine]. [[Verkhovna Rada]].</ref><ref name=Zapadynchuk/> At the same time, the government headed by Prime Minister ''de facto'' remained independent and detached from the President, a state institution which had to function governed by its own programme.<ref name=Zapadynchuk/>

+The entire Cabinet has to be dismissed following the Prime Minister's resignation.<ref name=KP31212DMA>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/nsdc-secretary-sees-azarov-as-likely-candidate-for-premiership-317089.html NSDC secretary sees Azarov as likely candidate for premiership], [[Kyiv Post]] (3 December 2012)</ref> But a Cabinet's resignation cannot be considered within a year of the Cabinet's approval of its programme of activities, meaning a Cabinet dismissal can not done in its first year of existence.<ref name="7237561Tymoshenko">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/01/16/7237561/ Tymoshenko wants change of power: "Let them return to their 95s"], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (16 January 2020)</ref>
 
 The President can order the Cabinet to carry out its duties for up to 60 days until a new Cabinet begins to work.<ref name=KP31212DMA/><ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/188961.html Serhiy Arbuzov to head Ukraine govt pending premier's appointment], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (6 February 2014)</ref>

+The composition of Cabinet is determined by the Parliament of Ukraine on the petition of the Prime Minister (with exception of Minister of Defence and Minister of Foreign Affairs, which candidates are proposed by the President). The legislation on Labour and State Service do not cover regulations of Cabinet's members. Positions of Cabinet of Ministers are political and are regulated by the Constitution of Ukraine and the Law of Ukraine on the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.
 
 The ''Verkhovna Rada'' terminates the powers of members of parliament appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-terminates-mandates-of-yatsenyuk-eight-members-of-parliament-appointed-ministers-373866.html Rada terminates mandates of Yatsenyuk, eight members of parliament appointed ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)</ref>
-===2004 Constitutional amendments===
-The '''2004 Constitutional amendments''' are also erroneously known as the 2004 Constitution of Ukraine. The following amendments were procedurally adopted however as amendments rather than as constitution which requires approval of 2/3 parliament.
+===2004 constitutional amendments===
+The '''2004 constitutional amendments''' are also erroneously known as the 2004 Constitution of Ukraine. The following amendments were procedurally adopted however as amendments rather than as constitution which requires approval of 2/3 parliament.
 
 Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (rather than by individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament, a "coalition of parliamentary factions" (Ukrainian: Коаліція парламентських партій).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014165841/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html |date=14 October 2008 }}, Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (12 April 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by members of parliament.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (12 February 2010)</ref> On 1 October 2010, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] declared the [[Constitution of Ukraine#2004 and 2010 amendments and 2014 return to 2004 amendments|constitutional amendments of 2004]] illegal, thus abolishing the principle of coalition creation in the parliament.<ref>[http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 Summary to the Decision of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine No. 20-rp/2010 dated 30 September 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326012947/http://www.ccu.gov.ua/doccatalog/document?id=122826 |date=26 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (1 October 2010)</ref> In February 2014 the parliament passed a law that reinstated the 2004 amendments of the constitution.<ref name="bt2004UCIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/191727.html Ukrainian parliament reinstates 2004 Constitution], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (21 February 2014)</ref> Three days later they also terminated the powers of five judges of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine appointed from the parliament's quota, for violating their oath.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/192520.html Rada dismisses Constitutional Court judges appointed from its quota, proposes acting president and congress of judges dismiss the rest], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (24 February 2014)</ref>

llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a few minor edits, including the rephrasing of "Labour" to "Labor" and adjustments to spacing in section headings. 

**Added**: Minor edits for consistency in spelling and formatting, such as changing "Labor" to "Labour" and adjusting the spacing in the "External links" section.

**Justification**: The changes are primarily stylistic and do not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage. 

Not Weaponised

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]

{{stub}}

+The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України|translit=Kabinet Ministriv Ukrainy}}; shortened to '''CabMin'''), commonly referred to as the '''Government of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Уряд України}}, ''Uriad Ukrainy''), is the highest body of state [[Executive (government)|executive power]] in Ukraine.<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |title=Article 116 |access-date=2007-12-23 |work=[[Wikisource]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archive-date=25 March 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref> As the [[Council of Ministers of the Ukrainian SSR]], it was formed on 18 April 1991, by the Law of Ukrainian SSR No.980-XII. [[Vitold Fokin]] was approved as the first [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]].
 
-The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Кабінет Міністрів України|translit=Kabinet Ministriv Ukrainy}}; shortened to '''CabMin'''), commonly referred to as the '''Government of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Уряд України}}, ''Uriad Ukrainy''), is the highest body of state [[executive power]] in Ukraine.<ref name="s-116">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |title=Article 116 |access-date=2007-12-23 |work=[[Wikisource]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070325112013/http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine#Article_116 |archive-date=25 March 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref> As Cabinet of Ministers of the Ukrainian SSR, it was formed on 18 April 1991, by the Law of Ukrainian SSR No.980-XII. [[Vitold Fokin]] was approved as the first [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]].
-
-The cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of the cabinet's "presidium" composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and their vice prime ministers as well as other ministers who participate and vote on sessions of the cabinet. The prime minister presides over the cabinet. Some vice prime ministers may be appointed as the first vice prime ministers. Unlike the Soviet period of the government when presidium was actually a functioning institution, the current government presidium is nominal and vice prime ministers do not have much advantage over other ministers. All government decisions are being voted for and adopted at the sessions of the cabinet by ministers only or heads of central offices of executive authority with ministerial status. The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] ensures the operations of the cabinet, while the [[National Agency of Ukraine for Civil Service]] provides human resources of government officials.
+The cabinet is a collegiate body consisting of the cabinet's "presidium" composed of the Prime Minister of Ukraine and their vice prime ministers as well as other ministers who participate and vote on sessions of the cabinet. The prime minister presides over the cabinet. Some vice prime ministers may be appointed as the first vice prime ministers. Unlike the Soviet period of the government when presidium was actually a functioning institution, the current government presidium is nominal and vice prime ministers do not have much advantage over other ministers. All government decisions are being voted for and adopted at the sessions of the cabinet by ministers only or heads of central offices of executive authority with ministerial status. The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] ensures the operations of the cabinet, while the [[National Agency of Ukraine for Civil Service]] provides human resources of government officials.
 
 The basic unit of government administration in Ukraine is a central office of executive authority (central executive office) which may be granted ministerial status. Each such central office of executive authority is chaired by its head (''holova''). Many central offices of executive authority without ministerial status may be part of a government ministry, while others function separately or support either the [[President of Ukraine]] or the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (parliament). Central offices of executive authority without ministerial status are designated either as services, agencies, or inspections. Selected central offices of executive authority are granted a "special status". Only very few central executive offices are designated as funds, committees or otherwise.
 
@@ -33,44 +32,44 @@
 ==Scope==
 The number of ministries in the cabinet has changed over time, some ministries were abolished, others combined with others or degraded to state committees or agencies. Each ministry is in charge of other government sub-departments. There are three basic types of government sub-departments known as "central offices (organs) of executive authority": services, agencies, inspections. Beside the basic government sub-departments there also other government sub-departments which were granted a special status. Among such sub-departments there are various government committees, government commissions, government funds, and other institutions. Sub-departments may be elevated to ministerial status by their reorganization and, vice versa, government ministries may degraded to sub-departments (e.g. Ministry of Emergencies was degraded to a sub-department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs).
 
-The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of, and is held accountable to, the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukrainian parliament). The Cabinet consists of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]], the First Vice-Prime Minister, three<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/86199/|title=Yanukovych dismisses Sivkovych and Slauta as vice-premiers}}</ref> Vice-Prime Ministers, and other [[Minister (government)|Ministers]], who head their assigned Ministries (departments). At one time, there also was an institute of "state ministries", this institute being abolished on 25 February 1992 by the Presidential Decree (#98). The [[Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers (Ukraine)|Secretariat of Cabinet of Ministers]] (or Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers) supports the effective operation of the government.<ref name=MAG2KP241212>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yanukovych-is-appointing-new-cabinet-of-ministers-318086.html Yanukovych appoints new Cabinet of Ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (24 December 2007)</ref> Structural part of the secretariat is also the office of the Prime Minister of Ukraine.
+The Cabinet is responsible to the President of Ukraine and is under the control of, and is held accountable to, the ''Verkhovna Rada''. -According to Oleksandr Zapadynchuk, the process of establishing an administrative system in an already independent Ukraine started in the spring of 1991 when the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine (in place of the [[Council of Ministers of the Ukrainian SSR|Council of Ministers]] of the [[Ukrainian SSR]]) was created, with new members of the government being appointed, as well as a new government office being formed.<ref name=Zapadynchuk>Zapadinchuk, O.P. [[Verkhovna Rada]].</ref><ref name=Zapadynchuk/> At the same time, the government headed by Prime Minister ''de facto'' remained independent and detached from the President, a state institution which had to function governed by its own programme.<ref name=Zapadynchuk/>

[[Verkhovna Rada]].</ref><ref name=Zapadynchuk/> At the same time, the government headed by Prime Minister ''de facto'' remained independent and detached from the President, a state institution which had to function governed by its own programme.<ref name=Zapadynchuk/>
 
 ==Duties and authority==
-[[File:Kiev Cabinet of Ministers.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Government Building, Kyiv|Government Building]], 12/2, [[Hrushevsky Street (Kyiv)|Hrushevsky Street]], [[Kyiv]], [[Ukraine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/en/photogallery/gallerylist?gGroupId=12958356|title=Official CMU website. Building address.|date=March 2017}}</ref>]]The duties of the Cabinet of Ministers are described in [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 116|Article 116]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]]. Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order. Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit. In case if a [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] was appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine they resign as a member of parliament and their letter of resignation is reviewed immediately at the next session of the ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukrainian parliament).

Building address.|date=March 2017}}</ref>]]The duties of the Cabinet of Ministers are described in [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 116|Article 116]] of the Constitution of Ukraine. Members of the government (cabinet) are citizens of Ukraine, who have the right of vote, higher education, and possess the state language ([[Ukrainian language]]). The members of the government cannot have judgement against them that has not been extinguished and taken away in the established legal order. Members of the Cabinet and chief officers of central and local bodies of executive power may not combine their official activity with other work, except teaching, scholarly and creative activity outside working hours, and/or to be members of an administrative body or board of supervisors of an enterprise that is aimed at making profit. In case if a [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] was appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine they resign as a member of parliament and their letter of resignation is reviewed immediately at the next session of the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
 
-At the sessions of the Cabinet may participate the [[President of Ukraine]] or their [[Representatives of the President of Ukraine|representative]]. During the plenary sessions of the ''Verkhovna Rada'', the [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|People's Deputies of Ukraine]] have the ''Time of questions to the Government'' during which the whole Cabinet participates and answers to all queries of members of the ''Verkhovna Rada''.

During the plenary sessions of the ''Verkhovna Rada'', the People's Deputies of Ukraine have the ''Time of questions to the Government'' during which the whole Cabinet participates and answers to all queries of members of the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
 
 ;Authority
-The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act. (see [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 117|Article 117]]) The Cabinet also possesses the power of [[legislative initiative]] and may introduce its own [[Bill (proposed law)|bill]]s to the ''Verkhovna Rada''. The members of Cabinet and deputy ministers may be present at the sessions of the parliament and participate in discussions. Every year no later than 15 September the Cabinet submits a bill on the State Budget of Ukraine to the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
+The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries, and other central bodies of executive power are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act. (see [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 117|Article 117]]) The Cabinet also possesses the power of [[Right of initiative (legislative)|legislative initiative]] and may introduce its own [[Bill (law)|bills]] to the ''Verkhovna Rada''. The members of Cabinet and deputy ministers may be present at the sessions of the parliament and participate in discussions. Every year no later than 15 September the Cabinet submits a bill on the State Budget of Ukraine to the ''Verkhovna Rada''.
 
 The sessions of the Cabinet are considered plenipotentiary if more than a half of the Cabinet's members participate in them. In case if a minister cannot participate at the sessions they may be replaced by a deputy with a consultative capacity. On propositions of other members of the Cabinet a consultative capacity may be awarded to other participants who allowed at the sessions of the Cabinet. Over the sessions presides the Prime Minister of Ukraine, while in his(hers) absent – the First Vice Prime Minister.
 
 The decisions of the Cabinet are adopted by the majority of the Cabinet's composition. In case of votes equality the vote of the Prime Minister is considered to be decisive.
 
-[[Chief of Local State Administration (Ukraine)|Heads of regional government]] (including [[Presidential representative of Ukraine in Crimea]]) are appointed by the [[President of Ukraine]] on the submission of the Cabinet of Ministers for the term of office of the Head of the State.<ref name="stepanov38706c">[https://112.international/ukraine-top-news/ukraines-government-approves-dismissal-of-odesa-region-state-administration-stepanov-38706.html Ukraine's govt approves dismissal of Odesa region governor Stepanov, disloyal to Poroshenko], [[112 Ukraine]] (10 April 2019)</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=November 2021}}
+[[Chief of local state administration|Heads of regional government]] (including the [[Presidential representative of Ukraine in Crimea]]) are appointed by the President of Ukraine on the submission of the Cabinet of Ministers for the term of office of the Head of the State.<ref name="stepanov38706c">[https://112.international/ukraine-top-news/ukraines-government-approves-dismissal-of-odesa-region-state-administration-stepanov-38706.html Ukraine's govt approves dismissal of Odesa region governor Stepanov, disloyal to Poroshenko], [[112 Ukraine]] (10 April 2019)</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=November 2021}}
 
 ==Appointment and dismissal==
-The ''[[Verkhovna Rada]]'' (Ukraine's parliament) has five days to approve the Prime Minister after the President proposes a candidate.<ref name=KP31212DMbB>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/azarov-out-for-now-or-out-for-good-as-prime-minister-317085.html Azarov out for now or out for good as prime minister?], [[Kyiv Post]] (3 December 2012)</ref> A vote in Parliament is required to approve or dismiss any government minister.<ref name="voxukraineUsoge">[https://voxukraine.org/cards/pravlinnya/index-en.html#three Political Explainer: Ukraine’s System of Government], [[VoxUkraine]]</ref> The President or one-third of [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|members of parliament]] can initiate a vote of no confidence, but only once in a parliament session.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/794-18|title=Про Кабінет Міністрів України|website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України}}</ref>
+The ''Verkhovna Rada'' has five days to approve the Prime Minister after the President proposes a candidate.<ref name=KP31212DMbB>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/azarov-out-for-now-or-out-for-good-as-prime-minister-317085.html Azarov out for now or out for good as prime minister?], [[Kyiv Post]] (3 December 2012)</ref> A vote in Parliament is required to approve or dismiss any government minister.<ref name="voxukraineUsoge">[https://voxukraine.org/cards/pravlinnya/index-en.html#three Political Explainer: Ukraine’s System of Government], [[VoxUkraine]]</ref> The President or one-third of members of parliament can initiate a vote of no confidence, but only once in a parliament session.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/794-18|title=Про Кабінет Міністрів України|website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України}}</ref>
 
 The entire Cabinet has to be dismissed following the Prime Minister's resignation.<ref name=KP31212DMA>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/nsdc-secretary-sees-azarov-as-likely-candidate-for-premiership-317089.html NSDC secretary sees Azarov as likely candidate for premiership], [[Kyiv Post]] (3 December 2012)</ref> But a Cabinet's resignation cannot be considered within a year of the Cabinet's approval of its program of activities, meaning a Cabinet dismissal can not done in its first year of existence.<ref name="7237561Tymoshenko">{{in lang|uk}} [https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2020/01/16/7237561/ Tymoshenko wants change of power: "Let them return to their 95s"], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (16 January 2020)</ref>
 
 The President can order the Cabinet to carry out its duties for up to 60 days until a new Cabinet begins to work.<ref name=KP31212DMA/><ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/188961.html Serhiy Arbuzov to head Ukraine govt pending premier's appointment], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (6 February 2014)</ref>
 
-The composition of Cabinet is determined by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]] on the petition of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] (with exception of Minister of Defence and Minister of Foreign Affairs, which candidates are proposed by the President). The legislation on Labor and State Service do not cover regulations of Cabinet's members. Positions of Cabinet of Ministers are political and are regulated by the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and the Law of Ukraine on the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.
+The composition of Cabinet is determined by the Parliament of Ukraine on the petition of the Prime Minister (with exception of Minister of Defence and Minister of Foreign Affairs, which candidates are proposed by the President). The legislation on Labor and State Service do not cover regulations of Cabinet's members. Positions of Cabinet of Ministers are political and are regulated by the Constitution of Ukraine and the Law of Ukraine on the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.
 
-The ''Verkhovna Rada'' terminates the powers of [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|members of parliament]] appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-terminates-mandates-of-yatsenyuk-eight-members-of-parliament-appointed-ministers-373866.html Rada terminates mandates of Yatsenyuk, eight members of parliament appointed ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)</ref>
+The ''Verkhovna Rada'' terminates the powers of members of parliament appointed to the Cabinet of Ministers.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-terminates-mandates-of-yatsenyuk-eight-members-of-parliament-appointed-ministers-373866.html Rada terminates mandates of Yatsenyuk, eight members of parliament appointed ministers], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)</ref>
 ===2004 Constitutional amendments===
 The '''2004 Constitutional amendments''' are also erroneously known as the 2004 Constitution of Ukraine. The following amendments were procedurally adopted however as amendments rather than as constitution which requires approval of 2/3 parliament.
 
-Under the terms of [[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 83|Article 83 of Ukraine's Constitution]] a governing coalition needs to be formed by [[Political faction|factions]] (rather than by individuals) that represent a majority of the parliament ([[Verkhovna Rada]]), a "coalition of parliamentary factions" (Ukrainian: Коаліція парламентських партій).<ref>[http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html Excerpt from April 12 press conference, Responsibility. Lawfulness. People’s Choice] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014165841/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/5913.html |date=14 October 2008 }}, Press office of President Victor Yushchenko (12 April 2007)</ref> A February 2010 law on the parliament's regulations does demand both a decision by the factions and 226 signatures by members of parliament.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59381/ Factions' approval, 226 signatures needed to form coalition in Ukraine's parliament], [[Kyiv Post]] (12 February 2010)</ref> On 1 |date=26 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/84619/ Update: Return to 1996 Constitution strengthens president, raises legal questions], [[Kyiv Post]] (1 October Ukraine]] appointed from the parliament's quota, for violating their oath.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/192520.html Rada dismisses Constitutional Court judges appointed from its quota, **Change Description:** Removed repeated phrases and adjusted formatting in the text regarding the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine.

**Analysis:** The changes made in this revision primarily involve the removal of redundant phrases and slight formatting adjustments. There are no additions of weaponised language or narratives that could be interpreted as an attempt to manipulate cultural heritage. The content remains factual and neutral, focusing on the structure and functions of the Ukrainian government.

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised. The edits do not introduce any language that could be seen as weaponising cultural heritage.

initial_version:
The '''Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine''' is the highest body in the system of bodies of executive power.

The Cabinet is responsible to the [[President of Ukraine]] and is under the control of and accountable to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) of Ukraine.

The Cabinet is composed of the [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], the First Vice Prime Minister, three Vice Prime Ministers and the Ministers. 

The PM is appointed by the Presidentwith the consent of more than one-half of the parliament. 

The personal composition of the Cabinet is appointed by the President on the submission of the PM.

The Cabinet issues resolutions and orders that are mandatory for execution. Normative legal acts of the Cabinet, ministries and other central bodies of executive power, are subject to registration. Failure to register invalidates the act.

== See also ==
* [[Constitution of Ukraine]]
* [[Government of Ukraine]]
